questions.text: Which of the following scapula parts is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa
questions.solution:
The given figure is that of Scapula. Coracoid process is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa. A-Glenoid cavity, B-Acromian process, C-Coracoid process and D-Inferior angle



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 787,803

questions.text: Which of the following is the source of the structure marked C
questions.solution:
The structure marked as C here is the Azygos vein.The azygos vein originates from the supracardinal vein.The azygos vein is formed by the union of the ascending lumbar vein and right subcostal veins at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra. Structures are A – SVC, B – Arch of azygos vein, C – Azygos vein, D – Sympathetic chain. The azygos vein originates from th supracardinal vein. The supracardinal veins function to drain the body wall through intercostal veins formed from posterior cardinal veins.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e107,223

questions.text: Which nerve fibers passes from the marked structure?
questions.solution:
• The image given in the question points to the dorsal aspect of the brain stem.
  • CN IV (Trochlear Nerve) is the only cranial nerve that exits dorsally from the brainstem. All other cranial nerves exit from the ventral aspect.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e12

questions.text: A patient is admitted with a fracture at the base of the skull that affects the bones of the temporal and occipital regions. Following the trauma, he was unable to speak properly. Which of the marked structures would you examine in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this question, the fracture involves the junction between the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This junction contains the jugular foramen which transmits the 9th, 10th & 11th cranial nerves which may be injured and cause different symptoms. Since the clinical history is suggestive of dysarthria, we can check the uvula to examine the function of cranial nerves IX and X, by eliciting gag reflex. In the given image A- middle meatus, B- uvula, C- tongue and D- larynx


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 598,599,567,568

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the third section of the vertebral artery?
questions.solution:
Vertebral artery is one of the principal arteries that supply the brain. It is the first and largest branch of the first part of Subclavian Artery.It has four parts—

a) Cervical Part

b)Vertebral Part 

c) Suboccipital Part 

d) Intracranial Part,

the 3rd part of vertebral artery moves from foramen transversarium to foramen magnum reaching the posterior arch of the vertebra.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 418,589,590,827,828,1464.e84

questions.text: Which of the following complications is most likely to develop if a central line is inserted below this bone?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the left clavicle.The most common complication if Central line is inserted below clavicle is arterial puncture.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e115

questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by the inferior thyroid artery?
questions.solution:
Inferior thyroid artery arises from the thyrocervical trunk which arises from the 1st part of subclavian artery. It supplies thyroid and parathyroid glands along with the cervical part of esophagus. It doesn't supply thymus, thymus is supplied by Internal Thoracic artery. 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 590,1059

questions.text: Where does the fibers from the mammillary body go ?
questions.solution:
Mammillary bodies are a pair of small round bodies which are a part of the diencephalon and forms a part of limbic system, located at the anterior end of the fornix. They are important for processing of memories. Projection axons from two major fibre tracts: a descending mammilotegmental tract terminate in the tegmental nuclei of Gudden and ascending mammilothalamic tract terminates in the anterior complex of the thalamus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 523,524

questions.text: The patient had the following hand abnormality when he arrived at the OPD. Which nerve among the following is most likely damaged
questions.solution:
Ulnar Nerve supplies the intrinsic muscles of hand, the flexor carpi ulnaris and medial half of flexor digitorum profundus. The image in question shows a partial claw hand affecting the medial 2 fingers only. Hence this is more likely an ulnar nerve injury as only the medial fingers are affected and there is no ape thumb which is caused due to media nerve injury. (Thenar eminence atrophy)



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1,953

questions.text: A cast was used to treat a patient who had previously fallen from a great height. After the cast was removed, he had trouble walking properly. He was unable to lift his leg, and it continued to drag as he walked. Which of the following structures is most likely to have been effected?
questions.solution:
Gluteus Minimus and Medius cause abduction and medial rotation of hip They prevent sinking of opposite hip while walking. They are supplied by superior gluteal nerve. In the clinical question given, the patient complaints of dragging of leg while walking. This is referred to as Trendelenburg sign and is seen in paralysis of Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius due to Superior gluteal Nerve injury.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1377,1378

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the image below.
questions.solution:
Pelvic diaphragm is a muscular bed which gives support to the pelvic viscera and closes the pelvic outlet.

It is formed by the levator ani and coccygeus. Nerve Supply is by pudendal nerve (Root : S2, S3, S4).


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1256,1244

questions.text: Which of the following structures is incorrectly labeled
questions.solution:
The given image is of Respiratory epithelium. It is a type of ciliated columnar epithelium. It functions as a barrier to potential pathogens and foreign particles by secreting mucus and its mucociliary clearance. Lamina propria is incorrectly labelled as muscle layer.

questions.text: Which of the following is inhibited by the indicated cell in the image below?
questions.solution:
Given image is the histological image of cerebellum with marked structures being purkinje cells.

The purkinje cells carry the output from cerebella cortex to the cerebella nuclei. They are inhibitory to the deep nuclear cells.

questions.text: The concentrations of an anion are 100 mEq/l in ECF and 10 mEq/l in ICF. How much is this ion's equilibrium potential
questions.solution:
Nernst equation is used to calculate equilibrium potential of single ion. Formula = +/- 61 log [outside concentration]/[inside concentration]. Equilibrium potential = -61 log(100/10) =- 61 log 10 = -61mV


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 9

questions.text: Which of the following will not shift the O2 dissociation curve to the right
questions.solution:
Oxygen dissociation curve is the curve between O2 saturation and pO2. It is sigmoid shaped. Factors causing right shift in the curve— —Bohr Effect —Decrease in O2 —Increase in CO2 —Increase in H+ —Hyperthermia —Increase in 2,3 -BPG —High altitude exercise. --- Decrease in HbF.
Fetal hemoglobin, HbF actually has higher affinity for O2, hence the oxygen dissociation curve shifts to the Left. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 631

questions.text: Which of the following will not increase gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
Gastric hormone, histamine and acetylcholine stimulate H+ pump of parietal cells causing HCL release.

Factors decreasing gastrin secretion—

—Gastric Acid 

—Somatostatin 

—Secretin

—Gastric Inhibitory Peptide.

To remember out of all GIT hormones like gastrin , secretin, VIP, CCK-PZ only gastrin is the only one associated with increased HCl Secretion. Remaining hormones decrease HCl secretion.

ACh is part of the parasympathetic nervous system aka rest and digest system, hence increases HCl secretion.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 448,449,450

questions.text: Which of the following does not have the Na-I symporter (NIS)?
questions.solution:
Sodium- iodine cotransporters are present in thyroid, stomach, salivary gland, lactating mammary glands, placenta, ovaries.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 357,358

questions.text: Calculate the tetanizing frequency of the skeletal muscle from the given data: Latent period - 10msec, Contraction period - 40msec, Relaxation period - 50msec.
questions.solution:
Tetany is defined as the sustained contraction of a muscle due to increased frequency of stimuli. Tetanising frequency (Tf) of a muscle is inversely proportional to the contraction period. Tf= 1/40=25 per sec.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 107

questions.text: Except for which of the following, luminal concentrations in the kidney PCT will decrease?
questions.solution:
PCT is lined with cuboidal epithelium with a brush border. It increases the surface area for absorption. Almost all essential nutrients and 70-80 % of electrolytes and water are reabsorbed by PCT with small changes in luminal osmolarity. Hence urine is isotonic in the proximal convoluted tubule. 100% glucose, Amino acids absorbed but Cl- is not absorbed in PCT, hence it's concentration is not decreased in PCT. 


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 369,370,371

questions.text: What causes the majority of body heat loss at air temperatures of 47 degrees Celsius?
questions.solution: -Most of heat loss from body occurs by radiation under normal circumstances. When body temperature is more than Atmospheric Temperature. In the given question, the atmospheric temperature is 47°C which is much more than the body temperature. In such cases, there wont be heat loss from the body and heat is gained by the body as it is at a lower temperature. So the body can lose heat only by evaporation through sweating in this case.

questions.text: A patient with hypoxemia was brought to the emergency room. It was discovered that the alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) was normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Alveolar - arterial O2 gradient is the difference in pO2 between alveoli and blood in arteries. 
In hypoventilation, there is no defect in oxygenation of blood. Hence [A -a] gradient remains normal.


Among the given options:
 
  • Option 1: Right to Left Shunt—arterial O2 decreases and gradient increases.
  • Option 3: V/Q mismatch - Here the lung is ventilated properly but is not perfused well. As a result, arterial blood doesn’t get oxygenated properly and hence gradient is increased.
  • Option 4: Hyaline Membrane Disease - The process of diffusion of gases is affected here, so oxygenation of blood doesn’t take place properly and so gradient is increased.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2133, 2136, 2137.

questions.text: For a healthy 70 kg adult male whose basal oxygen consumption is 250 ml/min, how much MET would be required to equal oxygen consumption 1500 ml per minute?
questions.solution:
1 Metabolic Equivalent is defined as the amount of oxygen consumed while at rest and is equal to 3.5 ml/kg body weight/min.

For a 70 kg adult, 1 MET= 3.5 X 70 = 245 ml/min (250 ml/min) as given in question. When O2 consumption has increased to 1500 ml/min. MET Equivalent = 1500/250

= 6 MET


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 5

questions.text: Pacinian Corpuscle detects which of the following sensations?
questions.solution:
Pacinian corpuscles are present deep in dermis.  They are a type of touch receptor and detect high frequency pressure.

Other types of touch receptors—

—Meissners’s Corpuscles- Detects fine touch, low frequency vibration.

—Merkel Cells-  Sensitive to sharp edges

—Ruffini’s Endings- Detects Pressure Sensation.

Trick:- 
Pacinian- Pressure 
Pacinian- Piano- Piano produces music by vibration- Vibration sense


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 158

questions.text: Where is the maximum airflow resistance observed
questions.solution:
Resistance is maximum with medium sized airways. Resistance depends on the radius of airways and the type of flow in the airways. It is inversely proportional to radius to the power 4 and is directly proportional to turbulence. In medium sized airways, turbulence is present and radius is smaller compared to large airways hence resistance is more.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 619

choices.text: Decrease in slope of end diastolic pressure-volume curve
Increase in slope of end systolic pressure curve
Left shift of end systolic pressure-volume curve without change in slope
Left shift of end diastolic pressure-volume curve without change in slope

questions.text: A person's myocardial contractility was discovered to have risen. What impact will it have on the heart's volume-pressure curve
questions.solution:
When there is increase in myocardial contractility the end systolic volume decreases and stroke volume increases which will lead left shift of end systolic pressure-volume curve without change in slope. 



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 538

questions.text: What is explained by the genetic code's wobble theory?
questions.solution:
Crick proposed the 'wobble hypothesis' to explain the degeneracy of the genetic code. Except for tryptophan and methionine, more than one codons direct the synthesis of one amino acid. There are 61 codons that synthesis amino acids,therefore, there must be 61 tRNAs each having different anticodons. But the total number of tRNAs is less than 61.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: What is the most reliable method for estimating HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Gold Standard method for HbA1c is High Performance Liquid Chromatography.

Among the given options, Ion exchange chromatography is most suited.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Which of the following substances does not produce glucose?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA is purely ketogenic because Pyruvate Dehydrogenase enzyme is irreversible and acetyl CoA thus cannot form Pyruvate. Pyruvate is both glucogenic and ketogenic. Oxaloacetate, Citrate, Succinylcholine CoA, Fumarate are glucogenic.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 171.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has a defect in collagen maturation?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) can cause bleeding gums, petechiae and Ecchymosis. Vit C acts as coenzyme for hydroxylases. Therefore deficiency can lead to defective hydroxylation of proline and lysine resulting in defective collagen, thereby causing bleeding manifestation. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 43.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with restriction fragment length pair technique

questions.text: Which of the following methods is most suited for quantitative analysis of viral genomes
questions.solution:
In the given question, the target to be amplified is a viral genome. Hence RT - PCR is required for amplification and real time PCR for further quantification. RT-PCR is used to detect/quantify any kinds of RNA. Real time PCR is also known as quantitative PCR. Starting material is DNA. Used for simultaneous amplification + detection/quantification of amplicon.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: An unconscious patient with a history of not eating for more than two days is brought to the emergency room. Which of the following tests will be positive for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) only iii
 
  • In the given question, patient presents with history of starvation for more than 2 days which can result in production of ketone bodies.
  • Test for ketone bodies is Rothera’s test.
  • Positive test gives a purple ring. Positive in case of acetone and acetoacetate. Negative in case of Beta hydroxy Butyrate.

1st image - Benedict test - shows glucose in urine, which is absent in starvation, 2ns image - Heat and acetic acid test for proteins. 

Online Reference: Comstock JP, Garber AJ. Ketonuria. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 140. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK247/

questions.text: Lactic acidosis is caused by thiamine deficiencies. In this case, which enzyme activity is inhibited?
questions.solution:
Thiamine (Vitamin B1) acts as a coenzyme for various enzymes. Active form of thiamine is Thiamine Pyrophosphate (TPP).

Enzymes requiring TPP—

—Pyruvate Dehydrogenase

—Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase 

—Branched Chain ketoacid dehydrogenase 

—Transketolase.
In thiamine deficiency, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate is then converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase, leading to lactic acidosis.
Therefore, option 1, Pyruvate dehydrogenase, is the correct answer.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: Which of the following requires the most energy to assimilate?
questions.solution:
Assimilation of food refers to the thermic effect of food (TEF). It is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate required for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients.

It’s magnitude depends on composition of food consumed—

Carbohydrates : 5% - 15% of the energy consumed. 

Protein : 20% - 30% 

Fats : 5% - 15%.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 144.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about mitochondrial DNA?
(i) Higher chances of mutations as compared to nuclear genome
(ii) Single stranded circular DNA
(iii) Mitochondrial codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
(iv) Mitochondrial DNA codes for all the ETC complex proteins
(v) It has around 16000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is double stranded, circular and has about 16,569 base pairs.

Mutation rate is very high because of the absence of introns, protective histones and repair enzymes.

It codes for 13 ETC proteins and follows maternal inheritance.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 369.

questions.text: Which of the following lipids is not a substance that amphipathizes?
questions.solution:
Triacyl Glycerol (Neutral Fat) is the storage form of lipids in humans.

Triacyl glycerol and cholesterol esters are non-polar compounds whereas phospholipids, cholesterol and apolipoproteins are amphipathic compounds.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 248.

questions.text: Which of the following DNA repair procedures is used in CRISPR/Cas9 gene knockdown technology
questions.solution:
CRISPR/Cas9 gene is a defence mechanism in bacteria against phages. It codes for the enzyme Endonuclease Cas 9. This enzyme is used in cleaving mutation sites in Human DNA (double stranded breaks). Hence it helps in eliminating the problematic gene and replace it with the desired gene known as non-homologous end joining.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 447.

choices.text: The inhibitor binds to the active site where it is modified by the enzyme to produce a reactive group that reacts irreversibly to form a stable inhibitor-enzyme complex.
It is an irreversible form of enzyme inhibition that occurs when an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue and forms an irreversible complex with it through a covalent bond.
Inhibitor binds to all sites resulting in irreversible inhibition.
Inhibitors are unreactive until within the enzyme’s active site.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning suicidal inhibition is incorrect
questions.solution:
• It is a mechanism based irreversible form of enzyme inhibition.
  • The inhibitor forms an irreversible complex with the enzyme through a covalent bond.
  • The inhibitors are inactive till they bind to the active site of the enzyme.
  • Eg : Allopurinol Inhibiting Xanthine Oxidase.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 78.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements applies to a person with advanced liver disease?
(i) Hyperammonemia
(ii) Low ATP production
(iii) Conversion of alpha-keto glutarate to glutamate and then to glutamine is increased
(iv) Alpha-keto glutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) i, ii & iii

  • In case of advanced liver disease / liver failure, conversion of NH3 to Urea (Urea Cycle) doesn’t take place in the liver.
  • As a result, NH3 accumulates in the body, especially in the neurons of brain where they bind all the H+ ions to form NH4+.
  • Because of H+ ion depletion, there is decreased ATP production via the ETC. Alpha ketoglutarate is the scavenger of NH3. It binds to form Glutamate.
  • Glutamate binds with NH3 to form Glutamine (carrier of NH3).

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2549.

choices.text: Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 3’ UTR
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is increased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR
Ferritin translation is increased by binding of iron regulatory protein to 5’ UTR

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about intracellular regulation of iron metabolism
questions.solution:
Option(3) is correct.

When iron concentration is low
  • IRP(iron regulatory protein) binds to the 3' IRE (iron responsive element) and stabilize the mRNA for Tfr (transferrin receptor), increasing its translation  and allowing Tfr synthesis. (Hence, option 1 is incorrect. Option 2 is incorrect because IRP does not bind to 5' UTR of Tfr)
  • IRP binds to 5' IRE of ferritin prevents mRNA to synthesise ferritin (i.e. decreases Ferritin translation) - therefore option 3 is correct. 
When iron concentration is High
  • IRP dissociate from 3' IRE on transferrin receptor and lack of IRP causes decreased Tfr synthesis.
  • IRP dissociate from 5'IRE of Ferritin to allow mRNA to synthesise ferritin.(ie increase Ferritin)(therefore option 4 is incorrect - ferritin translation is not increased by binding of IRP to 5')
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 458.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a hallmark of Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Birbeck granules 

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a rare multisystem disorder characterized by the clonal proliferation of Langerhans Cells.
  • (Antigen presenting cell)
  • The Penta laminar tubules known as Birbeck granules, which contain the protein langerin are hallmarks of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
  • These Birbeck granules frequently have a dilated terminal end that gives them the appearance of a tennis racket.
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

choices.text: Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area viable and grey area necrosed.
Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.

questions.text: The sliced liver of a patient who passed away from heart failure is depicted in the following image. Which of the following statements is true based on the specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic venous congestion of Liver; dark area necrosed and grey area viable.
 
  • The given image in the question shows the nutmeg appearance of liver typically seen in chronic venous congestion of liver.
  • It is seen during right heart failure resulting in congestion of blood in the systemic organs. Because of chronic venous congestion, there is back pressure on the hepatic veins (central veins) resulting in necrosis of the central region which appears dark in color (centrilobular necrosis and periportal fibrosis). The periportal region remains viable and is grey in color.

Fig: Chronic Venous Congestion microscopic examination (nutmeg liver)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 517.

questions.solution:

* Epithelial tumors of ovary—

  • —Mucinous

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1017.

questions.text: Which of the following does not feature splenomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Aplastic anemia
 
  • Aplastic Anemia is a condition in which there is complete absence of both intra and extramedullary hemopoiesis. Hence there is no splenomegaly in this case.
  • Lymphoma and leukemia present with splenomegaly Due to splenic involvement by malignant cells. 
  • Hairy cell leukemia has bone marrow infiltration resulting in extramedullary hemopoiesis presenting as splenomegaly.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 659.

questions.text: A patient's peripheral blood analysis revealed lymphocytosis with smudge cells. Which of the following investigations is most likely to yield a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flow cytometry

The given clinical history is suggestive of Chronic Lymphocytic Lymphoma.
Clinically presents with lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, anaemia (autoimmune haemolytic anemia).
Flow cytometry helps us arrive at a definitive diagnosis and rule out important differential diagnosis.

Flow cytometry—

CD19+, CD20+, CD5+ CD23+.

Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 336.

questions.text: A child with proptosis and little extraocular movement presents to the OPD. Chloroma is tentatively diagnosed. Which of the following investigations is the best suitable for evaluation?
questions.solution:
In the context of a child with proptosis and limited extraocular movement where chloroma (a myeloid sarcoma) is tentatively diagnosed, the best suitable investigation for evaluation would be 2. Peripheral smear.

A peripheral smear can help identify the presence of abnormal cells, such as blasts that are indicative of myeloid leukemia or chloroma. This investigation would provide immediate information about the type of cells in circulation, which is crucial for diagnosing hematological conditions. Other options like platelet count, leukocyte count, and hemoglobin estimation are useful but would not directly provide the necessary diagnostic information for chloroma as effectively as a peripheral smear would.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 620.

questions.text: A 50-year-old industrial worker arrives at the OPD with a cough and dyspnea. Upon examination, it was discovered that he had lung fibrosis and pleural thickening. The lung biopsy resulted in the following discovery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Asbestosis

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Asbestosis. It is an occupational lung disease especially seen in shipping industry. Occurs because of chronic exposure to Asbestos. Patient complaints of cough, dyspnea.
  • It usually affects the lower lobes of lung and presents as —Pleural plaque (Most Common Lesion), Lung Cancer or malignant mesothelioma (Most specific finding of asbestosis, needs about 25 years of exposure). H&E demonstrates asbestos/ferruginous bodies (dumbbell shaped bodies)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 695.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who had been experiencing exertional dyspnea for the previous month presented to the OPD. He had experienced significant mitral stenosis. A prosthetic valve was used to replace his sick valve. A biopsy was taken from the removed valve. Determine the disease implicated and the typical biopsy finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff nodules, Rheumatic Heart disease

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.
  • It is an immunologically mediated multi - system disease. It is caused due to type 2 hypersensitivity reaction which usually occurs 2-3 weeks after a Beta haemolytic Streptococcal infection. This is due to molecular mimicry of Streptococcal Antigen with glycoprotein in heart and joints. In chronic rheumatic fever, patient develops mitral stenosis. Diagnosis is by Revised Jones Criteria.
  • Aschoff Bodies (Pathognomic for RHD) consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, giant cells, fibrinoid necrosis, collagen and cells with wavy, slender, ribbon - like nucleus (Caterpillar cells/Antischkow Cells)


Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

choices.text: Type IV hypersensitivity - epitheloid cells, giant cells, macrophages

questions.text: A patient who arrives at the hospital has had a cough and low-grade fever for the past two weeks. An X-ray of the chest revealed caseous necrosis in the lung's apex. What is the disease's underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type IV hypersensitivity - epithelioid cells, giant cells, macrophages 
 

  • The given clinical history (low grade fever, cough for 2 weeks) is suggestive of TB infection of lung, caused due to inhalation of Mycobacterium Tuberculosis.
  • The inhaled organism activate cell mediated immunity (type 4 hypersensitivity) resulting in the formation of an epithelioid granuloma with central caseous necrosis.
  • Granuloma is composed of slipper shaped cells called epithelioid cells; multinucleated giant cells called Langhan’s Giant cell with a central area of necrosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: For which of the following is FISH performed
questions.solution:
Her2/neu is a membrane receptor that belongs to the human epidermal growth factor receptor family. Amplification/ over expression is associated with increased risk of breast cancer.
Her 2/neu is graded as :
Her 2/neu 0,1 —negative
Her 2/neu 2–Equivocal result - FISH test is required to finalise
Her 2/neu 3–positive.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: The karyogram below demonstrates a chromosomal defect. Location of the chromosome where the mutation has occurred is
questions.solution:
• Chromosome 13 is normally acrocentric, but in the given image - the arrow is pointed at the centromere located at the center of the chromosome showing a metacentric translocation defect. Hence, option(2) is the correct answer, not option(1).
  • Classification of chromosomes Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are classified as—
  1. Metacentric: Both p and q are of equal size (p = q).
  2. Submetacentric: The q arm is slightly longer than the p arm (p < q).
  3. Acrocentric: The p arm is very small compared to the q arm (p <<< q).
  4. Telocentric: The p arm is completely absent. This type does not exist in humans.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 631

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy arrives at the emergency department complaining of neck swelling. Cervical lymphadenopathy was discovered during the examination. Following a lymph node biopsy, HPE revealed the image below. Identify the cancer and the characteristic feature.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hodgkin’s with R-S cells; EBV infection

  • The given image shows Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) which are considered pathognomic/typical of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • They are distinct neoplastic giant cells (30-60 um in size) with abundant cytoplasm, 2 large nuclei, and 2 large inclusion like nucleoli giving an Owl Eye appearance that stimulate reactive lymphocytes, histiocytes (macrophages), and granulocytes to assemble in large numbers. Reed Sternberg cells in a background of inflammatory cells infiltrate are diagnostic of Hodgkin's Lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin's Lymphoma is typically associated with EBV infection.  


* [Extra Edge]: Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells)



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: A boy who has a history of fever, night sweats, and neck swellings visits the OPD. A biopsy of the swellings revealed a starry sky look. Identify the likely gene mutation responsible for the given ailment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) C-myc

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of Burkitt’s Lymphoma.
  • It is the most common type of NHL in children < 15 years.
  • It is also commonly associated with EBV infection. Lymph Node Biopsy: Starry Sky appearance
  • It is a cancer of B lymphocytes present in germinal center.
  • It can arise from genetic defects: t (8:14), t (2:8), t (8:22). t (8:14) - Resulting in increased expression of c - myc (oncogene) causing increased cell proliferation.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 289.

questions.text: After being stung by a bee, a patient develops anaphylaxis. Identify the antibody that is causing this reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IgE

  • The given history is suggestive of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction to a bee sting. It is mediated by Ig E antibody.
  • Type I hypersensitivity involves immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen.
  • This results in mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.
  • Most immediate hypersensitivity (Type I) disorders are caused by excessive Th2 responses, and these cells play a central role by stimulating IgE production and promoting inflammation.
  • When a mast cell armed with IgE antibodies previously produced in response to an antigen is exposed to the same antigen, the cell is activated, leading to the release of an arsenal of powerful mediators that are responsible for immediate hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g., those in bee venom).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 205.

questions.text: Which of the following cell cycle phases is the least radio sensitive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. S Phase.

According to law of Bergonie and Tribondeau, Radiosensitivity is directly proportional to mitosis and inversely proportional to differentiation.
 
  • Most radiosensitive phase of cell cycle : G2/M transition phase. (G2> M)
  • Cell cycle is composed of 4 major phases :
  1. G1 : Gap Phase I (Resting Phase)
  2. S : Synthesis Phase (DNA replication occurs here)
  3. G2 : Gap Phase (Resting Phase)
  4. M : Mitosis (Cell division takes place).
  • During S phase cells are actively synthesizing DNA , hence tend to be more resistant to radiation induced damage. Even if damaged it easily undergoes repair. 

Summary of radio sensitivity of various tissues-




Note- Most common organ affected due to radiation is skin. Among all the layers, Stratum basalis is the most affected due to presence of actively dividing cells.



Reference: Basic Radiotherapy Physics and Biology, 2014 edition, Page no 293.

choices.text: can be used during sentinel lymph node biopsy
helps to check for negative tumor margins

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about frozen sections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 3) provides definitive diagnosis in all cancers

*[Extra Edge]: Frozen section in Diagnostic Pathology

  • It is a pathological laboratory procedure done to perform rapid microscopic analysis of a specimen. Mainly used in oncological surgery. 
  • It can be used for diagnosis in many cases, but quality of slides produced is lower compared to formalin fixed paraffin embedded tissue processing (gives more accurate diagnosis).
  • Intraoperative assessment of resected specimens to check whether resection margins are clear of the tumor.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy to check for presence of tumor in dissected lymph nodes, to check for suspected metastasis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 275.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with heart failure and is scheduled for a heart transplant. His RFT is erratic and his Hb is 6 gm%. The patient received transfusion with two units of whole blood. He experiences acute respiratory distress and fever four hours later. He has high MAP and hypoxemia. Which are the most effective investigations in this case

i. Chest X-ray
ii. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) level
iii. Absolute neutrophil count
iv. Leucocyte antibodies
v. Platelets
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. i, ii (Chest X ray & BNP levels)
 
  • The clinical scenario describes an elderly patient with heart failure who experiences severe respiratory distress, hypoxia, tachycardia, and elevated mean arterial pressure after a blood transfusion. The most likely diagnosis is transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Recommended investigations for suspected TACO include a chest X-ray and BNP levels.
 
  • A chest X-ray in TACO may reveal bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates, while BNP levels are typically elevated due to volume overload. It’s important to note that anti-leukocyte antibodies are found in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), not in TACO patients.
 
  • TACO is primarily a clinical diagnosis, suspected in any patient who develops acute respiratory distress or hypertension during a transfusion or within six hours after it ends. Risk factors for TACO include older age, pre-existing fluid overload, cardiac dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and the transfusion of large blood volumes.
 
  • Management of TACO involves stopping the transfusion and administering oxygen and diuretics.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about TACOTransfusion-associated circulatory overload) is correct?
(i) Chest X-ray showing congestion
(ii) Fever
(iii) Dyspnea
(iv) Hypotension
(v) BNP <200pg/ml
questions.solution:
Statements (i) and (iii) are correct for TACO.

  • Evidence of acute or worsening pulmonary edema (CXR shows vascular congestion, pleural effusion etc.) and dyspnea are seen in TACO(Transfusion-associated circulatory overload)
  • BNP<200 pg/mL, Fever, and Hypotension are commonly seen in TRALI (Transfusion-associated Acute Lung Injury), not TACO.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895.

questions.text: Which cells are impacted in newborns with respiratory distress syndrome
questions.solution:
Type 2 pneumocytes are affected. Respiratory distress syndrome is seen commonly in pre - term neonates and babies born to diabetic mothers. There is decreased production/lack of surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes present in alveoli of lung. As a result there is collapse of alveoli resulting in respiratory distress (tachypnea, chest retractions, grunting and cyanosis). In the given image, A- capillary, B- Type I pneumocye, C- Type II pneumocye and D- lamellar body



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 316

questions.text: Which specimen is stained with oil-red O
questions.solution:
Oil red O stain is used in the staining of fats (triglycerides & lipids). Among all the options given only the frozen section preserves the fat content. Alcohol and aldehyde fixatives dissolve the fat present in the specimen and hence can’t be stained by Oil red O stain.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 787.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man arrives at the OPD with a left-sided testicular tumor and ataxia. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Non-Hodgkins lymphoma
 
  • According to the given history the patient is most likely to have Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma.
  • Non - Hodgkin’s Lymphoma can involve extra nodal tissues (testes, GIT, brain, etc) and hence it is the most likely answer for this question. Glioblastoma is seen in the brain and it rarely metastasises to the testes.
  • Non - seminomatous Germ Cell Tumour can present with testicular swelling but ataxia is less likely. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma usually presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, it rarely involves extra nodal tissues.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 592.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a milk pasteurization test
questions.solution:
Pasteurization is a technique used for the disinfection of milk. The efficacy of Pasteurisation can be checked by : 1. Phosphatase test: Enzyme destroyed by heat, so it is absent in pasteurized milk. 2. Standard plate/Colony count: It will be <30000 colonies/ml in pasteurized milk. 3. Coliform Test: E.coli in milk indicates fecal contamination, it is zero in pasteurized milk
Pasteurization is the process of applying heat, to milk for a specific period (71 degree Celsius for 15 seconds) followed by rapid cooling to 10 degree Celsius or less, for the purpose of killing pathogenic. There are two methods, Holder method and Flash method.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 635.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option with respect to JE.
(a) Culex mosquito (i) Accidental host
(b) Man (ii) Reservoir host
(c) Pig (iii) Amplifier host
(d) Ardeid birds (iv) Vector
(v) Paratenic host
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis is caused by Group B Arbovirus belonging to Flaviviridae. It is a zoonotic disease and man is an accidental host. Vector is culex mosquito. Ardeid birds are the reservoir/maintenance host for this virus.
Pigs act as the amplifer host in which the virus multiplies. Man is an accidental host and has a dead end infection (can’t transmit to other humans).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 527.

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option.
 
(a) Hymenolepsis nana (i)
(b) Ascaris (ii)
(c) Hookworm (iii)
(d) Taenia (iv)
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Hymenolepsis nana- Oval in shape with the presence of six hooklets. It is non-bile stained.



Taenia- Spherical thin hyaline embryonic membrane with the fully developed hexacanth embryo at the centre.



Hookworm- oval in size, space between ovum and eggshell and the presence of 4-8 blastomeres.



Ascaris- Mostly round, golden brown colour with a large unsegmented ovum at the centre.




Reference: Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology, 8th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: Which of the following is an obligate anaerobic organism?
questions.solution:
• Prevotella is an obligate anaerobe.
  • Aerobic and anaerobic bacteria can be identified by growing them in test tubes of thioglycollate broth.
  • Obligate anaerobes are poisoned by oxygen and gather at the bottom of the tube where O2 is lowest while obligate aerobes gather at the top of the tube where O2 concentration is highest.
  • Prevotella resides in the oral and respiratory tract. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 274.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old non-immunized child reported to the OPD with pseudomembrane over the tonsils. A sample of the throat was collected, stained, and inspected under a microscope. Choose the correct stains from the options provided.
(i) Albert stain 1
(ii) Albert stain 2
(iii) Iodine
(iv) Acetone
(v) Methylene blue
(vi) Safranin
(vii) Water
questions.solution:
The given image shows a microscopic image of a Coryenebacterium diptheriae (History of pseudomembrane/unvaccinated child points towards diphtheria) stained with Albert’s stain.

Albert’s Staining is a type of differential stain that stains metachromatic granules/volutin granules of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Albert stain is composed of two reagents— Albert stain 1 and 2 which are applied to slide respectively.

Albert Solution 1:

  • toluidine blue, malachite green, glacial acetic acid, and alcohol

Albert solution 2:

  • Iodine and Potassium iodide in water


Albert's, Neisser's and ponder's stain are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules (Volutin/Babes Ernst granules) of corynebacterium diphtheria.

Among the given options, best answer is option (1).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 673.

questions.text: Identify the location of lipid A in the provided gram-negative bacterial cell wall.
questions.solution:
Gram negative bacteria has certain special structures in their cell wall when compared to gram positive bacteria. They are : Outer membrane , Periplasmic space and Endotoxin/LPS.
Lipid A is a part of the structure of endotoxin, embedded in outer membrane and has the actual endotoxic activity.
https://images.app.goo.gl/R5Ae6ij5uemqvqp4A Image for explanation.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the attachment effacement lesion depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
E.coli is a gram negative bacteria which is the most common facultative anaerobe present in human GIT.

EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli) is an example of diarrheogenic E. coli. It is the most common cause of infantile bacterial diarrhea. It consists of enterocyte effacement plasmid which causes attachment - effacement effect leading to secretory diarrhea.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 285.

questions.text: Which of the following is the basis for the Paul-Bunnel test?
questions.solution:
Heterophile antibodies are antibodies directed against external antigens which cross react with self antigens.

In Paul - Bunnell test, heterophile antibodies in the patient’s blood sample is made to react with sheep, horse or cow red blood cell antigens. This works on the principle of latex agglutination reaction.

Paul - Bunnell test was used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis by Ebstein - Barr Virus (EBV).

In patients with IMN, there is production of heterophile antibodies.

Other examples of Heterophile antibodies: -

  • Weil-Felix test
  • Monospot test
  • Cold Agglutination test 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: Identify which virus has the lifecycle listed below.
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is that of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV). Steps of HSV replication cycle— 1. Binding to cell surface. 2. Entry after fusion of the membranes. 3. Capsid transport to the nucleus. 4. Transcription and translation. 5. Replication followed by capsid assembly. 6. Glycosylation 7. Glycoprotein export to the cell surface 8. Glycoprotein - containing plasma membrane endocytosis. 9. Envelopment : Glycoproteins within early endosomes fare with capsids in the cytoplasm. 10. Viral release.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 437.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal species is dematiaceous
questions.solution:
Dematiaceous moulds contain melanin in their hyphae walls. Eg : Madurella, Piedra, Cladosporium.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 605.

Sandfly is allowed to bite a hamster infected with leishmaniasis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of xenodiagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rabbit ileal loop toxin study

  • Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.
  • It is mainly used in the diagnosis of Chaga’s disease, Arboviral infections, Trypanosomiasis.
  • Rabbit ileal loop study is for food poisoning of clostridium.
Online Reference:
Duncan CL, Sugiyama H, Strong DH. Rabbit ileal loop response to strains of Clostridium perfringens. J Bacteriol. 1968 May;95(5):1560-6. doi: 10.1128/jb.95.5.1560-1566.1968. PMID: 4297020; PMCID: PMC252176.

questions.text: What is a drug's half-life if its elimination rate constant is 0.05/hr
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 13.9 hr

Plasma half-life (t½) of a drug is the time taken for its plasma concentration to be reduced to half of its original value.
Elimination rate constant (k) of the drug is the fraction of the total amount of drug in the body which is removed per unit time.
     
      * t1/2 = ln2/k 
      * t1/2 = 0.693/ Elimination Rate Constant = 0.693/0.05=13.9 hr.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: Which of the following does an anionic and slightly acidic medication often bind to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Albumin

  • Drugs can either be acidic or basic in nature. Depending on this, they bind to different plasma proteins in the blood.
  • Acidic drugs tend to bind to basic plasma proteins like Albumin. Eg : NSAIDs, Warfarin, Aspirin.
  • Basic drugs bind to acidic plasma proteins like α1 - acid glycoprotein. Eg. Opiods, Tricyclic antidepressants, amiodarone.
* The clinically significant implications of plasma protein binding are:
 
  • (i) Highly plasma protein bound drugs are largely restricted to the vascular compartment, so they tend to have smaller volumes of distribution.
  • (ii) The bound fraction is not available for action. However, it is in equilibrium with the free drug in plasma and dissociates when the concentration of the latter is reduced due to elimination.
  • (iii) High degree of protein binding generally makes the drug long acting, because bound fraction is not available for metabolism or excretion, unless it is actively extracted by liver or by kidney tubules.
  • (vi) In hypoalbuminemia, binding may be reduced and high concentrations of free drugs may be attained, e.g. phenytoin and furosemide.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 25.

questions.text: What are the bases for the drug classifications A, B, C, D, and X?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Safety in pregnancy

The Classification is based on safety in pregnancy.

  1. Category A - No demonstrable risk to the foetus. Eg : Levothyroxine, Folic Acid.
  2. Category B - Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the foetus and there are no adequate and well controlled studies in pregnant women. Eg : Metformin.
  3. Category C - Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on fetus.
  4. Category D - Positive evidence of human fetal risk, but potential benefits may warrant use of drugs in pregnant women despite potential risk. Eg : Losartan.
  5. Category X - Animal studies have demonstrated foetal abnormalities. Eg, Atorvastatin.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 101.

choices.text: Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A
Drug B increases the systemic metabolism of drug A
Drug B decreases the intestinal absorption of drug A
Drug B increases the renal clearance of drug A

questions.text:
The data for drug A's AUC alone and when coupled with drug B are shown in the following table. The p value is 0.0
DRUG Area Under The Curve (AUC)
A alone 550 \(\pm\) 150
A plus B 850 \(\pm\) 150
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Drug B decreases the first pass metabolism of drug A

The most accurate interpretation of this data is that Drug B reduces the First Pass Metabolism of Drug A.

AUC (Area under the curve) demonstrates the extent of absorption of a drug. The given data has a p-value < 0.01 which is significant. According to the given data, AUC of drug A is increased when combined with drug B. This implies that drug A is absorbed better when combined with drug B.

First - pass metabolism refers to the metabolism of a drug that occurs in the liver and intestine after absorption from the gastrointestinal tract before it reaches the systemic circulation. If first - pass metabolism is reduced, more of the drug will reach the systemic circulation, resulting in increased bioavailability and a higher AUC.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 34.

questions.text: Which dosage of dopamine favorably affects beta-1 receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 2-10 mcg

Dopamine is a catecholamine and is an important neurotransmitter in the brain. Dopamine has a dose dependent action on autonomic nervous system.

At 0 - 2 mcg/kg/min dosage, dopamine is more active on D1 receptors. Action on these receptors cause diuresis.

At 2 - 10 mcg/kg/min, dopamine acts on Beta 1 receptor thereby increasing cardiac contraction. 

At > 10mcg/kg/min, dopamine acts on alpha 1 receptor causing vasoconstriction. ( used in management of cardiogenic shock).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 146.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension occurs when blood pressure is not controlled despite the use of three types of antihypertensive medicines. Which of the following classes of medications must the patient be taking to meet the criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Diuretics
 

  • Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains high despite the use of 3 different classes of anti-hypertensives, one of which must be a diuretic. Especially Thiazide group of diuretic. 
  • The underlying cause of resistant hypertension is increased production of aldosterone. The drug of choice for resistant hypertension is spironolactone.

Here is an updated table with the treatment strategies for each type of hypertension:

Type Definition Treatment
Resistant Hypertension Blood pressure remains above target despite the use of 3 antihypertensive drugs, including a diuretic, at optimal doses. Optimize medication (adding spironolactone). 
Refractory Hypertension Extremely difficult to control blood pressure despite 5 or more drugs, including a diuretic. Consider renal denervation
Hypertensive Emergency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) with acute target organ damage (e.g., stroke, heart failure, renal failure). Intravenous antihypertensive agents (e.g., nitroprusside, labetalol, nicardipine) to rapidly lower blood pressure under close monitoring.
Hypertensive Urgency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) without acute target organ damage. Oral antihypertensive agents (e.g., labetalol, captopril, clonidine) to lower blood pressure gradually over hours to days.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 616.

questions.text: A man arrives at the OPD with a history of falling. He is hypertensive with a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently taking captopril, atenolol, aspirin, and amiodarone. As indicated in the graphic, he offers the following findings. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Amiodarone induced skin lesion   

  • The given image shows a bluish discoloration of skin of face. It is a common side effect associated with long term use of Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
  • The skin deposits result in a photodermatitis and a gray-blue skin discoloration in sun-exposed areas, the malar regions.
Option 1 Lupus pernio is a characteristic sign present in chronic Sarcoidosis. Rashes involved Raised skin lesions not maculopapular rashes.
Option 2 Captopril Toxicity may lead to allergic maculopapular skin rashes, but the malar gray blue skin discoloration described in the image is characteristic of Amiodarone.
Option 4 Silver toxicity also known as Argyria is a condition where deposits of silver build up in your body at toxic levels. This causes your skin and nails to turn bluish gray, but the Clinical scenario given in the above question has nothing to do with silver toxicity.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with hepatic cirrhosis is admitted after presenting with severe ascites. Which of the following diuretics is best for mobilizing the edema fluid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Eplerenone
 
  • In hepatic cirrhosis aldosterone is raised, therefore the doc is aldosterone antagonists like Spironolactone and Eplerenone. 
  • However, in severe cases furosemide is used in combination with aldosterone antagonists.
  • But according to the question the best diuretic best for mobilizing edema fluid among the given options remain, Eplerenone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 635.

questions.text: Which is the most effective drug used for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
• Vareniciline is an α4β2 partial agonist.
  • It is the most effective monotherapy for smoking cessation.
  • Side effects include Increased suicidal thoughts and depressive/psychotic symptoms.
  • It is more effective than other smoking cessation medications such as bupropion and nicotine replacement therapy (nicotine gum, patches, lozenges, etc.) and has been shown to increase the chances of successfully quitting smoking by up to three times compared to placebo
  • It is started 1 week before the target date of cessation and therapy is continued for 12 weeks. 
  • Side effect- Suicidal thoughts 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 134.
Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 684

questions.text: Which one of the following medications is an opioid antitussive
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Levopropoxyphene
 
  • Levopropoxyphene is derived from propoxyphene which is an opioid.
  • Propoxyphene is a racemic mixture of Levo - propoxyphene and dextro - propoxyphene. Levo - propoxyphene is used as an antitussive while dextro - propoxyphene is used as an analgesic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 239.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to treat depression
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Vilazodone

Vilazodone is used in the treatment of major depressive disorder. It inhibits serotonin reuptake like SSRIs, and it is also a partial agonist at 5HT1A receptors. Lurasidone controls schizophrenia and depression in people with bipolar disorder but it does not cure these conditions.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 294.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants should be avoided in a patient with angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amitriptyline

  • Angle closure glaucoma occurs when the iris bulges. The bulging iris partially or completely blocks the drainage angle.
  • As a result, fluid can't circulate through the eye and pressure increases. Angle-closure glaucoma may occur suddenly or gradually. T
  • Therefore, anticholinergics are contraindicated in such patients as it will worsen the angle closure by pupillary dilation. Among antidepressants, maximum anticholinergic action is seen with tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) like Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline, Clomipramine, Imipramine.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 483.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in treatment of both seizures as well as neuropathic pain?
(i) Gabapentin
(ii) Lamotrigine
(iii) Carbamazepine
(iv) Pregabalin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) i, iii, iv

  • Among the given options, Gabapentin, Pregabalin and Carbamazepine are used in the treatment of neuropathic pain and seizures.
  • Gabapentin and pregabalin act by increasing GABA release at synapse by binding to presynaptic calcium channels and blocking endocytosis of calcium.
  • Carbamazepine is a sodium channel blocker. It is the drug of choice in the treatment of partial seizures and trigeminal neuralgia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations of saquinavir will improve its bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ritonavir

  • Saquinavir is a protease inhibitor used in anti - retroviral therapy.
  • They are metabolized by CYP3A4 and hence act as inhibitors of CYP3A4.
  • Ritonavir is the most potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and is used in combination with other protease inhibitors to boost their action and bioavailability.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 33.

questions.text: A patient on phenytoin for seizure disorder was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcer. What should be the minimum duration between consumption of two drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 120 min

  • Sucralfate is a gastroprotective agent used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease, oesophageal ulcers and as prophylaxis in radiation proctitis and stress ulcers. It acts by increasing prostaglandin secretion and also increases gastric pH.
  • Phenytoin is a weakly acidic drug and is absorbed from the stomach. Sucralfate raises the gastric pH, hence phenytoin will be in ionised form and can’t be absorbed normally.

So, a minimum gap of 2 hours must be present between consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate for phenytoin to be effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: What is Remdesivir's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Inhibits RNA dependent RNA polymerase

  • Remdsivir is a nucleotide analogue that stops COVID - 19 viral replication by inhibiting RNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It is the only FDA approved drug used in the treatment of COVID - 19 infection. It is used only in moderate and severe COVID - 19 cases that require hospitalisation and has to be used within 10 days of disease onset.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1223.

questions.text: Which of the following cephalosporins can make warfarin work more effectively, causing an elevated INR and a higher risk of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cefoperazone

Cephalosporins that contain methylthiotetrazole can cause hypothrombinemia leading to bleeding manifestations as it interferes with vitamin K metabolism. Eg. Cefoperazone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 670.

questions.text: What is Cyclosporine's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Calcineurin inhibitor

  • Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor.
  • It is used as an immunosuppressant medication.
  • It works by decreasing the function of lymphocytes by forming a complex with cyclophilin to block the phosphatase activity of Calcineurin which in turn decreases the production of inflammatory cytokines by T - lymphocytes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 937.

questions.text: Which of the following best illustrates how organophosphorus chemicals reduce acetylcholine esterase inhibition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Irreversible inhibition

Acetyl Choline Esterase has two sites— esteratic and an ionic site. The anioic site accommodates the positive quarternary amine of Ach while the esteratic site hydrolyses the Ach into Acetate and Choline.
In case of OP poisoning, Organophosphates bind with PO4 in the esteratic site reversibly but later the PO4 bond is replaced by a much stronger bond (ageing) making the binding irreversible, preventing the ACh from binding to the enzyme.
 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 47.

choices.text: Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulpha drugs.
Ceftriaxone is the better IV drug compared to ampicillin
Some strains of H. influenza have developed modified penicillin-binding proteins

questions.text: Following a diagnosis of H. influenza pneumonia in a 14-month-old kid, ampicillin was originally prescribed, followed by ceftriaxone. What are the reasons for this decision
questions.solution:
• Earlier, the drug of choice in H. Influenza pneumonia used to be Ampicillin. But in recent years, there has been increasing reports of resistance to ampicillin among H. influenzae bacteria due to production of beta lactamase and alteration in the penicillin binding protein. 
  • In such cases, the most effective drug to treat such an infection is Ceftriaxone.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, remains effective against most β-lactamase-producing and PBP-modified strains of H. influenzae and is often used when resistance is suspected or when initial empirical therapy with ampicillin fails. It offers broad-spectrum activity and has excellent central nervous system penetration. 



Reference- Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 379

choices.text: Soft tissue crushed between weapon and bone

questions.text: Following a car accident, a patient is taken to the emergency department. A 3x1 cm lacerated bone-deep wound is seen over the scalp. Which of the following best describes the proper mechanism of this lacerated wound?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history, the lacerated wound would most likely be a split laceration.

Laceration is defined as the splitting of epidermis/dermis/subcutaneous tissue caused by a heavy blunt force.

Types of laceration—

+Stretch laceration : Due to a tangential force on skin. Eg : Being run over by a vehicle.

+Shearing Laceration : Skin tissue gets avulsed and remains attached by a small margin of tissue (flaying).

Eg : Being run over by a vehicle at an acute angle.

+Cut Laceration : Spindle shaped gaping wound also known as chop/slash wound. 

+Split Laceration, also known as incision looking laceration on bony prominences.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 190.

questions.text: A case of a hanging victim is brought in for an autopsy. Upon inspection, the right eye was open, and saliva was seen trickling from the mouth. Which of the following structures is compressed, causing the right eye to open
questions.solution:
Hanging is a type of asphyxial death in which there is neck compression and body suspension. Eye on the opposide side of knot remains open and pupil dilated due to compression of cervical sympathetic ganglion. This is one of the signs of antemortem hanging, known as La facies Sympathique.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Following an explosion, a person was brought to the casualty area, where he was found dead. There were numerous, closely spaced abrasions and lacerations on the right side of the chest and abdomen. What was the cause of these injuries?
questions.solution:
Injuries mentioned in question are secondary blast injuries caused by projectiles generated by blast. It can cause Abrasions, Contusions, Lacerations (punctate) : Marshall Triad.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 240.

questions.text: A patient arrives at OPD with a right thigh injury. Upon examination, a sodden burn injury with erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation running down the limb is discovered. Which is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Based on the given history, the patient appears to have sustained a scald. They are burns produced by hot liquid > 60°C or by steam. On examination, skin is red, blisters seen. There is no singeing of hair, destruction of skin or blackening of skin. Clear line of demarcation is present at site of contact.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 329.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who works in the dye industry arrives at the OPD with throat pain, vomiting, dark red feces, and conjunctivitis. Which of the following compounds is most likely responsible for this
questions.solution:
Based on the given history patient is most likely suffering from acute arsenic toxicity.
The patient can present with a garlicky odor, nausea, vomiting, burning pain in the throat and abdomen, conjunctivitis, and painful micturition. It mimics cholera disease.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: Two friends get into a fight after consuming alcohol. One of them pushes the other to the floor and covers his face, stopping him from breathing while sitting on his chest. What's this known as?
questions.solution:
Based on the history given the mechanism of death here is burking. The person has died due to asphyxia by suffocation. It is a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
A person lies on the chest of the victim, preventing breathing and also covers the nose and mouth (face) with his hands.

History- This method of killing was developed by William Burk and William Hare who used to intoxicate homeless people kill them by Burking and used to sell their bodies to an Anatomy Professor. 


Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 364.

questions.text:
Identify the laws governing insanity from the available options.
(i) Curren’s
(ii) Durham
(iii) Ashby
(iv) Murphy
questions.solution:
Durham’s rule—Acts that are the “products” of mental disease or defect excuse criminal liability.
Curren’s rule—It states that an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirement of law, as a result of mental disease or defect.
Both are not used currently in India.

Memorizing Trick:- Criminal Responsibility- Insane CAN Defend 
Insane- Irresistable impulse test
C- Curren's rule 
A- American Law Institute
N- McNaughten's rule 
Defend- Durham rule

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 494.

questions.text:
In relation to fingerprint alterations, match the following:
(a) Ridge atrophy (i) Dermatitis
(b) Permanent loss of fingerprints (ii) Acromegaly
(c) Ridge alteration (iii) Radiation
(d) Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy (iv) Scleroderma
(e) Increased distance between ridges (v) Coeliac disease
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-v, e-ii
 
  • Fingerprints are papillary ridges on fingers which are unique. Fingerprints are the best method for criminal identification as it is not even identical in identical twins (Quetlet Rule).
  • Permanent loss of fingerprints occur in leprosy, electorcution (charring) and radiation. Ridge atrophy is seen in Coeliac disease, dermatitis.
  • Ridge alteration is seen in acanthosis nigricans scleroderma, eczema. Increased space between ridges is noted in acromegaly.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 84.

questions.text:
The skeleton bones of a dead body were discovered by police officers doing a routine examination in a nearby forest. They were sent to the hospital for forensic examination and identification. Only the pelvis was in good condition. Which of the following features would indicate a male pelvis

(i) Inverted ischial tuberosity
(ii) U-shaped subpubic angle
(iii) Small, deep, narrow greater sciatic notch
(iv) Large acetabulum
(v) ischiopubic index 80
(vi) small triangular obturator foramen
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. i, iii, iv, v

The pelvis is considered the best bone for sex determination. Small, deep, narrow greater sciatic notch, Large acetabulum and Ischiopubic index of 80 indicates a male pelvis.


Fig: Male and Female Pelvis

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 61.

questions.text:
