1. 2.
3. 4.
questions.solution:
In case of bilateral external auditory canal atresia, the device used is bone - anchored hearing aid. (BAHA)

Other indications for BAHA—

Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 137

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given NCCT scan
questions.solution:
The given images shows an NCCT of sinuses (coronal view) with the marker showing a pneumatised superior turbinate. Hallar cell is a anterior group ethmoidal air sinus present on the floor of the orbital cavity. Concha bullosa refers to a pneumatised middle turbinate. Onodi cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell and is closely related to optic nerve

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 153

questions.text: Post total laryngectomy rehabilitation, which of the following is not used?
questions.solution:
After total laryngectomy, supraglottic prosthesis can’t be used as it can’t be fixed properly in the absence of larynx.

Polite yawning is done in patients who have undergone laryngectomy as part of rehabilitation of olfaction. Voice rehabilitation can be done by two methods—

Oesophageal speech and tracheo—esophageal prosthesis.( best technique for production of voice in a post laryngectomy patient.)


Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 352

questions.text:
Patient was operated for safe CSOM in right ear. He then presented with
complaints of vertigo, tinnitus & ear fullness. He experienced relief on
turning his head to the opposite side. Identify his condition.
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical history, patient develops tinnitus, vertigo and ear fullness which are signs of labyrinth (inner ear) pathology.

He developed his symptoms just after surgery for CSOM which imples that he could have had an inner ear injury during the surgery. Among the given options, perilymphatic fistula is most appropriate as it is common after middle ear surgeries like that of CSOM. Perilymphatic fistula is the formation of abnormal communication between the perilymph filled inner ear and outside the inner ear.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 129

questions.text: A 76-year-old female patient who complained of persistent nasal discharge and sporadic epistaxis was seen in the ENT OPD. Here are the results of her CT scan. Which diagnosis is conceivable?
questions.solution:
Based on the history given, the most likely diagnosis is an inverted papilloma.

It is the most common tumour of nasal cavity, caused by HPV and arising from lateral wall of nose.

Clinical symptoms of nasal discharge, epistaxis are present and there is no evidence of bony erosion or intracramial extension.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 228

questions.text: Identify the given ophthalmologic finding:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Vossius ring.

  • It is commonly seen after blunt truma to the eye.
  • A circular ring of fainted or strippled opacity is seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule.
  • It is due to striking of contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens, which results in impression of the iris on the lens during trauma. The ring is always smaller than the size of the pupil.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: Name the following chart.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Hess chart. It is used in assessing diplopia; to asses the degree of paresis, measurement of deviation, udentify the paralysed muscle and differentiate between mechanical and neurogenic cause.


Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 370.

questions.text: Based on the patient's visual field investigation, determine the location of the lesion in the optic pathway.
questions.solution:
The given image shown an example of bitemporal hemianopia (loss of temporal eye field of both the eyes) due to injury at the optic chiasma. The most common intrinsic lesion is the pituitary adenoma which may promote compression of the optic chiasm causing visual disturbances. Other causes include third ventricular gliomas and craniopharyngioma.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 913, 914.

questions.text: What part of the brain is responsible for hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Among the options given, parietal lobe is the most appropriate answer.

Hand - eye coordination is the coordinated control of eye movement with hand movement and the processing of visual input to guide reaching and grasping along with the use of proprioception of the hands to guide the eyes.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 529,529.e1

questions.text: What is the most common ophthalmological symptom of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
• Most common ophthalmic manifestation of COVID - 19 is follicular conjunctivitis. It is the inflammation of conjunctiva that is usually associated with viral infections. Examination shows appearance of follicles in the palpebral conjunctiva.
 
  • Severe hemorrhagic conjunctivitis and pseudomembrane formation have also manifested several days after the onset of COVID-19 systemic symptoms.



Reference: Hu K, Patel J, Swiston C, et al. Ophthalmic Manifestations of Coronavirus (COVID-19) [Updated 2024 May 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556093/

questions.text: What stage of cataract surgery is depicted in the picture?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the capsulorrhexis step of cataract surgery (Anterior capsulotomy).

Anterior Capsule is stained using Trypan blue and is opened up using 2 techniques—Continuous Curvilinear Capsulorrhexis (CCC) and  Can opener technique.

choices.text: Life expectancy at one year, income, literacy rate
Life expectancy at birth, decent living standard, knowledge
Life expectancy at one year, income, decent living standard
Infant mortality rate, decent living standard, knowledge

questions.text: The Human Development Index consists of:
questions.solution:
Human Development Index (HDI) is an indicator used in assessing the overall well being of a population. It is a geometric mean. It has the following components—

1. Life expectancy at birth.

2. Knowledge—Mean schooling years and Expected years of schooling.

3. Decent Standard of living : Income (Gross National Income per capita).Range of HDI— 0 to 1.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 17.

questions.text: A medicine does not cure an illness; it only lowers the death rate. Which of the following is true in this situation?
questions.solution:
Prevalence of a disease refers to the total number of cases of that disease in a community at a particular point of time.
Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases of that disease that arise in a community for a specified period of time.

According to question, the new drug helps reduce mortality of a disease but doesn’t cure the disease. So the total no. of cases in the community will keep rising as survival of diseased people is increased. There is no change in incidence of the disease as nothing is done to prevent the occurrence/increase the occurrence of the disease.

Therefore, the prevalence of the disease increases while the incidence remains the same.

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 69.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent steps is not included in the case-control study?
questions.solution:
Follow up is a part of cohort study not case control study. Also known as retrospective study.

It has 3 distinct features—

1. Both exposure and outcome (disease) have occurred before the start of study. 

2. Study proceeds backwards from effect to cause. 

3. Uses a control or comparison group to support or refuse an inference.

Steps—

1. Selection of cases and controls.

2. Matching

3. Measurement of exposure

4. Analysis ( Odd’s ratio is calculated)

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 79.

questions.text: Which method is best for determining how strongly exposure and outcome are associated?
questions.solution:
The best suited study to asssess the strength of association between exposure and outcome is cohort study.

  • Also known as prospective study or incidence study.
  • Proceeds from cause to effect.
  • Cohorts are identified prior to the appearance of the disease under investigation.
  • The study groups so defined are observed over a period of time to determine the frequency of disease among them. 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 87.

questions.text: All the following steps apply to meta-analysis, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• Meta - analysis is a method of statistical analysis that pools summary data (Eg : means, relative risk, etc) from multiple studies for a more precise estimate of the size of an effect.
  • It also estimates the heterogenecity of effect sizes between studies.
  • 4 steps of meta- analysis—

       1. Identification

        2. Selection

        3. Abstraction

        4. Analysis.

Randomisation is not a step in meta - analysis.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 90.

questions.text: What is an example of the most recent surge in NCDs?
questions.solution:
Based on the frequency of disease in a population in relation to time distribution, diseases can have :

  • Short term fluctuations (Epidemics) ,
  • Periodic fluctuations (Cycles or Seasonal) and
  • Long term fluctuations (Secular Trends).

NCDs have shown secular trend of increase in number of cases.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 74.

questions.text: What does the external validity of a test imply?
questions.solution:
• External validity is the validity of applying the conclusions of a scientific study outside the context of that study. It represents the extent to which the results of a study can be generalised to and across other situations, people and times.
  • Internal validity is the validity of conclusions drawn within the context of a particular study.
NOTE:
  • Internal validity: are the results of the study valid for the sample of patients who were actually studied. Internal validity is increased by randomisation.
  • External validity: are the results of the study valid for the population from which the sample in the study was drawn. If the external validity of a study is such that it applies to other populations as well, it is said to be generalizable. External validity is increased by random sampling.
Reference: High Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 68.

questions.text: What antigen is used to produce the Hepatitis-B subunit vaccine?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B vaccine is a type of recombinant vaccine on Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) inserted into yeast (Saccharomyces). It was the first human vaccine produced by recombinant DNA technology.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

questions.text: What are the applications of age-adjusted mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Age adjusted/Age specific death rates refers to the death rates in a population distributed according to the age groups.

  • It is useful in comparing mortality rates of two different populations by calculating standardised mortality rates.
  • Standardisation is of two types— direct and indirect.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which of the following substances can be utilised for both induction and intubation alone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sevoflurane

  • Sevoflurane is the best answer among the given options.
  • Sevoflurane has the smoothest induction and is the least irritative to respiratory system. It is the preferred agent in day - care surgeries.
* [Extra Edge]: Sevoflurane
 
  • Induction and emergence from anesthesia are fast so that rapid changes in depth can be achieved.
  • Absence of pungency makes it pleasant and administrable through a face mask.
  • Unlike desflurane, it poses no problem in induction and is frequently selected for this purpose. Acceptability is good even by pediatric patients.
  • Recovery is smooth; orientation, cognitive and motor functions are regained almost as quickly as with desflurane.
  • Sevoflurane is suitable both for outpatient as well as inpatient surgery, induction as well as maintenance, but its high cost and need for high-flow open or semi closed system makes it very expensive to use.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 408.

questions.text: Emergency cardiopulmonary resuscitation followed by rapid administration of 20% intralipid solution is done in which of the following scenario:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV administration of local anesthetic 
Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetics results in a phenomenon known as Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST).

Features of LAST:

  • CNS- Tinnitus, Blurring of vision, dizziness, circumoral numbness, agitation, restlessness, muscle twitching leading to GTCS. CNS depression, unconsciousness and finally respiratory arrest.
  • CVS- Prolonged PR intervals, widened QRS complexes, sinus bradycardia, cardiac arrest. Ventricular arrythmias also occurs. CVS manifestations are more prominent with Bupivacaine than other Local anesthetic agents.
Prevention- 
Withdraw the stylet of syringe and watch whether blood enters the syringe. If doesn't give the local anesthesia, if blood comes then change the location of injection. 
 

Treatment:
If a patient experiences profound cardiovascular depression or circulatory arrest after the administration of bupivacaine, ropivacaine, or by extrapolation, other local anesthetics, then along with initiation of basic life support and the ACLS protocol, a rapid bolus of Intralipid 20%, 1.5 mL/ kg (approximately 100 mL in adults) is recommended, followed if necessary by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min over the next 10 minutes.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 885.

questions.text: In conventional O2 therapy, the device can supply oxygen at a maximum rate of:

In conventional therapy, the device with highest oxygen delivering capacity is NRBM. So the max flow rate through it is 15-16 L/min,.

questions.text:
A lap cholecystectomy was being performed on an obese ASA-2 patient. His ETCO2, spO2, blood pressure, and peak airway pressure all unexpectedly plummeted to 8mm Hg, 90%, and 80/50mm Hg, respectively. What might be the potential reason?

questions.text: A young child appears with the asymptomatic lesions depicted below on the dorsum of the hand and penile shaft. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct option is (4) Lichen Nitidus.

  • The given image shows a lesion suggestive of Lichen nitidus.

Among the given options lichen planus has purple, pruritic,polygonal lesions; Sacbies has burrow lesion; Scrofuloderma is cutaneous manifestation of TB

questions.text: The limbs of a 68-year-old patient had itchy, tense skin blisters on the extensor aspect, as depicted below. What would the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows tense bullae on urticarial red base which are most likely due to bullous pemphigoid.
  • It is an immunobullous disorder where antibodies are directed against BPAG - 2 and BPAG - 1 present in hemidesmosomes.
    There is sub - epidermal split in the skin resulting in formation of tense bullae which have red, urticarial bases. Histopathology shows sub - epidermal bullae with eosinophils.
  • Direct immunofluorescence study shows a linear pattern of IgG, C3 deposition in the basement membrane zone.

Treatment— steroids.

Below is an image which can be used to diagnose different Bullous conditions based on the keywords

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 50.2

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of the following condition?
questions.solution:
• Fluocinolone is a steroid and is not used in the treatment of acne as steroids can exacerbate acne.
  • Treatment includes topical retinoids and anti-bacterial depending on the grade/severity of disease.


Reference:Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 90.37, 90.38, 90.40

questions.text: The patient had vesicular sores over his chest that were localized to one area on one side and complained of pain in he same side. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Herpes zoster (shingles) arises due to the reactivation of Varicella Zoster virus infection within the dorsal root ganglion. It is characterised by a painful, unilateral vesicular eruption, usually in a dermatomal distribution.

Treatment : Amitryptilline, Pregabalin, Gabapentin.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 447.

questions.text:
The face and neck of a patient from Bihar who had a history of persistent fever as a youngster were affected by nodular, hypopigmented lesions.
Both hypoaesthesia and nerve thickening were absent. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given history (h/o prolonged fever in childhood, living in Bihar) and clinical findings are suggestive of post - Kala Azar dermal leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is transmitted by sandfly (Phlebotomus Argentipes).

  • PKDL is a complication of Kala Azar following complete/incomplete/irregular treatment of Kala-azar.
  • It presents as macular/papular/nodular skin rash.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

choices.text: 50% of cases resolve spontaneously after bacillus exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than adults
Indeterminate leprosy resolves more spontaneously than tuberculoid leprosy
Most clinical cases do not resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement about leprosy?
questions.solution:
Leprosy is a chronic infectious granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and nerves. Corrected options—

Option A : 95% of cases resolve spontaneously 

Option B : Children recover better from leprosy than adults. 

Option C : Indeterminate leprosy resolve better than tuberculoid 

Option D : Leprosy doesn’t heal by itself in multibacillary type. Even though option B is correct, Option C is more acurate and factual.

Audio explanation of the above.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 373.

questions.text: Following a work-related prick injury, a rose gardener had the following alterations to their skin. What might be the causing factor?
questions.solution:
The given image is showing nodulo - ulcerative lesions along the lymphatics suggestive of sporotrichosis( Rose gardener’s disease) caused by Sporothrix Schenkii. Infection arises following traumatic implantation of the fungus (rose prick). H & E shows cigar shaped yeast arranged in structures called asteroid bodies. Culture reveals hyaline septate molds at 25°C - 28°C, dimorphism can be proved by yeast conversion test.

Treatment : Itraconazole.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 606.

choices.text: Triad of acute onset confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

questions.text: Which of the following assertions concerning Korsakof syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
Korsakoff psychosis or Korsakoff syndrome is a long term/chronic manifestation of alcohol toxicity. It is characterised by anterograde amnesia and filling up holes in recent memory with made up facts (confabulation). It is due to the involvement of mamillary bodies and anterior thalamic nuclei.
Triad of GOA- Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia and Ataxia is seen in Wernicke's syndrome.
Management include Thiamine supplementation and rehabilitation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 534.

choices.text: Depression is a common comorbidity in OCD
Atypical antipsychotics are the first line treatment
Prevalence of OCD in general public is 7-10%

questions.text: Which of the following statements about OCD is correct?
questions.solution:
• OCD is a thought possession disorder in which a person has intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and/or feels the need to perform certain routines repeatedly (compulsions) to an extent where it induces distress or impairs one’s general functioning.
  • One of the most common types of obsession is “fear of contamination” and " Pathological doubt". (option 2 is incorrect)
  • SSRIs are the first line of treatment. (option 3 is incorrect)
  • The prevalence of OCD in the general public is 2% - 3%. (option 4. is incorrect)
  • It is commonly associated with depression, anxiety, and distress. 


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 418-425.

questions.text: Which of the following  procedure would be contraindicated in patient whose CXR is shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: ICD insertion.

  • The given image shows elevation of left hemidiaphragm with presence of bowel and stomach beneath it.
  • In such a scenario, insertion of chest tube is contraindicated as the X-Ray findings could be due to diaphragmatic injury following blunt trauma in road traffic accident. 
  • Blunt trauma to the diaphragm results in linear diaphragmatic rupture, which if large, can lead to herniation of abdominal contents into chest. 
  • Management- Primary repair via abdominal approach to manage associated visceral injuries.

ICD insertion could injure viscera therefore it is contraindicated.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 377.

questions.text: After being struck by a bull, a 30-year-old patient later complained of abdominal pain for the past three days, obstipation, and nausea, and vomiting for the last two days. After being initially stabilized, he now complains of worsening abdominal pain, and an examination revealed rigidity in his abdomen. The results of a CT scan are shown below. What is the most probable reason for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Hollow viscus perforation.

  • The given axial CT scan of the abdomen shows presence of air in the peritoneal cavity beneath the anterior abdominal wall. 
  • The given radiographic findings along with clinical features of obstipation, worsening abdominal pain and rigidity in the abdomen points towards diagnosis of pneumoperitoneum secondary to hollow viscus perforation. 
  • Most common cause of pneumoperitoneum in adults- Hollow viscus perforation
  • Most common cause in neonates- Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Best X-Ray projection- Erect chest X-Ray PA view
  • Investigation of choice- CT Abdomen 

The various named signs in pneumoperitoneum are as follows:




Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 205, 1048, 1049, 1052.
Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1236, 1455.

questions.text: Determine the investigation from the illustration below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: USG.

The given image shows the ultrasonogram view of neck region



The salient features of neck ultrasound is as follows:
•    Non-invasive, lacks radiation exposure and is readily available at a low cost. 
•    Best imaging modality to study the thyroid gland in neck for both diffuse and nodular disease. 
•    USG guided fine needle aspiration in the most effective method of diagnosing malignancy of thyroid. 
•    After partial/near total thyroidectomy for carcinoma, ultrasound is the preferred method for follow-up, by detecting residual, recurrent or metastatic disease. 
•    TIRADS can be used to stratify the risk of malignancy of thyroid nodule according to its ultrasonographic characteristics. 
•    USG guided ablation with chemical agents/thermal energy can be used to treat thyroid adenoma and benign cold nodules. 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 882.

questions.text: What statement regarding CORADS is accurate?
questions.solution:
CORADS is a CT based system that is sued to assess the suspicion of pulmonary involvement in COVID -19.

CORADS score of 5 is indicative of typical COVID infection.
 

Findings of COVID-19:

—Bilateral, peripheral & lower zone predominant airspace opacities (GGOs, consolidations) on X - ray.

—Bilateral, sub pleural, peripheral GGOs, airspace consolidations, crazy pavement patterns on CT. 

—Reverse halo/Atoll sign: central area of GGO with surrounding consolidation.






Reference: Prokop, Mathias et al. “CO-RADS: A Categorical CT Assessment Scheme for Patients Suspected of Having COVID-19-Definition and Evaluation.” Radiology vol. 296,2 (2020): E97-E104. doi:10.1148/radiol.2020201473. URL: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7233402/

questions.text: What is the reason for the double bleb sign on USG?
questions.solution:
• The double bleb sign is an important USG finding confirming pregnancy.
  • The double bubbles are formed by the amnion and the yolk sac. It is seen at 5-6 weeks of IUL.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 237.

questions.text:
Which of the following diagnostic techniques is used to identify placenta accreta?
(i) USG
(ii) MRI
(iii) CT scan
(iv) Angiography
questions.solution:
• Some features of placenta accreta on ultrasound are loss of normal hypoechoic plane in the myometrium beneath the placental bed, presence of multiple placental lacunae, loss of normal hyperchoic line separating the urinary bladder wall from the uterus, thinning of the myoemtrum to less than 1 mm, buldging of the placenta into surrounding organs adjacent to the uterus, causing a mass like lesion protuding out from the uterine wall
  • The demonstration of uterine bulging and loss of normal uterine contour on MRI suggests Accrete
  • On T2 weighted MR images, the mass is hyperintense and may be heterogeneous
  • Also, T2 weighted MR images are useful in the assessment of focal thinning of the myometrium and interruption of the junctional zone
Other options-
  • CT scan gives x ray exposure moreover it is not good for diagnosing placenta accreta.
  • Angiography has no use in diagnosing placenta accreta. 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 761, 762.

questions.text: A patient arrived with symptoms including clay-colored feces, generalized itching, and jaundice. His CBD was also dilated, and his ultrasonogram revealed a swollen gall bladder without any signs of stones. Which of the following investigations comes next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2. Endoscopic ultrasound

The given clinical history (jaundice, generalized itching, clay-colored stools) is suggestive of obstructive jaundice.

  • His USG shows evidence of a distended gall bladder and dilated CBD which implies that the obstruction must be distal to the CBD and most likely at the periampullary region.
  • The best imaging modality to check for obstruction at the peri-ampullary region is endoscopic ultrasound as it offers the benefit of taking a biopsy in case of peri-ampullary carcinoma.
Other options-
  • x ray and PET scan are of no use. 
  • Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography is an invasive procedure so it is not the next line investigation. 


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1496.

questions.text: What causes c waves in JVP?
questions.solution:
Jugular venous pressure is the indirectly observed pulse pressure over the venous system via visualisation of the internal jugular vein. 

JVP waveform—

Classically it has three upward deflections and two downward deflections. a wave : Right atrial contraction.

c wave : Isovolumetric contraction of right ventricle. x descent : Pulling of tricuspid valve downward during ventricular ejection. v wave : Venous filling when tricuspid valve is closed causing rise in venous pressure. y descent : Rapid emptying of the atrium into the ventricle following the opening of tricuspid valve.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: What medication can be used for a cluster headache attack that is acute?
questions.solution:
Cluster headache is a neurologic disorder characterised by recurrent severe headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye.

It often lasts for 15 minutes to 3 hours, attacks occur in clusters which typically lasts for weeks to months and occasionally more than a year.

Treatment:

  • Cluster headache attacks peak rapidly, and thus a treatment with rapid onset is required. Many patients with acute cluster headache respond very well to oxygen inhalation.
 
  • This should be given as 100% oxygen at 10–12 L/min for 15–20 min.
 
  • It appears that high flow and high oxygen content are important. Sumatriptan 6 mg SC is rapid in onset and will usually shorten an attack to 10–15 min; there is no evidence of tachyphylaxis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3366.

questions.text:
Multiple TIA events were experienced by an elderly patient with severe MS with atrial fibrillation. Which of the following assertions about stroke prevention in this patient is correct?
(i) Only aspirin is given in prevention of stroke
(ii) Warfarin is used in prevention of stroke
(iii) Dabigatran is not indicated
(iv) Mitral valvotomy is indicated in this case
questions.solution:
• Statements (ii) and (iii) are correct regarding stroke prevention in this patient.
  • Statement (i): Clopidogrel combined with aspirin is more effective than aspirin alone for stroke prevention. Warfarin is superior to antiplatelet therapy for stroke prevention.
 
  • Statement (ii): Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant for patients with mitral stenosis (MS) and mechanical prosthetic valves.
 
  • Statement (iii): Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) such as dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban are not used for treating moderate to severe MS or in patients with prosthetic heart valves due to limited clinical evidence. DOACs have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage than warfarin and are as effective as warfarin for stroke prevention in valvular heart disease (except for moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves), ischemic stroke or TIA, and atrial fibrillation (AF).
 
  • Statement (iv): Mitral valvotomy is not recommended for stroke prevention in this patient. It is indicated for symptomatic patients (New York Heart Association Functional Class II-IV) with isolated severe mitral stenosis, where the effective orifice area is less than 1.5 cm² in normal-sized adults. It is contraindicated in the presence of left atrial thrombus.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 935, 1906, 1992, 3344.

questions.text:
Identify the type/stage of hepatitis infection in a patient based on the results of the provided serological tests:
HBsAg - negative
HBcAg - negative
HBeAg - negative
HBV DNA - negative
IgM Anti-HBcAg - negative
IgG Anti-HBcAg - positive
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Recovered from hepatitis B
All antigens are negative except igG anti HBcAg which indicates past infection but HBsAg is negative indicates recovered from HBsAg
The positivity of IgG Anti-HbcAg alone indicates past infection. Since HbsAg is negative, it can be understood that the patient has recovered.
Other options- For chronic hepatitis b, the Positivity of HbsAg along with IgG Anti-HbcAg is observed.
For the window period, the presence of only IgM Anti-HbcAg is observed.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 552.

questions.text:
Shortness of breath, bilateral pedal edoema, and right upper abdominal pain are the symptoms a 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with. His JVP was discovered to be raised upon examination, and his liver is palpable 8 cm below the right costal edge.
Which heart chamber is not functioning properly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Right ventricle

  • The given signs and symptoms (pedal edema, tender hepatomegaly, raised JVP) is suggestive of right sided heart failure which is due to the inability of right ventricle to pump blood efficiently.
  • Shortness of Breath occurs due to decreased capacity of right ventricle to pump enough blood for oxygenation resulting in accumulation of blood in veins, causing dyspnea

* [Extra Edge]: Signs of right sided heart failure

—Raised JVP.

—Kussmaul sign (Rise in JVP on inspiration) 

—Tender hepatomegaly. 

—B/L pitting oedema. 

—Abdomino - Jugular reflux present.

Right sided heart failure is often caused by pulmonary heart disease (Cor Pulmonale).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

questions.text:
A vaso-reactivity test was negative in a patient with grade II pulmonary artery hypertension.
Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Based on vaso - reactive test., If positive (inhaled Nitric Oxide cause PAH < 10 mm Hg with BP and CO normal), Ca2+ channel blockers are used.
 
  • If negative, endothelin antagonists (Bosentan, Ambrisentan) are preferred. Drugs like prostacyclin analogues and PDE - 5 inhibitors (Sildenafil) are also used in advanced cases.


Treatment strategy overview for patients with newly diagnosed pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH):



Low- or intermediate (Int)-risk patients are initiated on combination oral therapy, which generally includes an endothelin receptor antagonist and phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2128.

choices.text: Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF 30-40% as compared to HFpEF 15%
ACE inhibitors leads to angioedema in 1% cases and dry cough in 10-15% cases
5yr mortality in heart failure is around 50% regardless of EF or type of heart failure
In elderly atrial fibrillation is common and constitutes quarter of stroke cases

questions.text: In relation to cardiac failure, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Option 1– In Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF), majority of deaths in this group occurs due to non-cardiovascular causes.  In Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF), majority of deaths arise due to cardiovascular causes.

Option 2– ACE inhibitors cause cough and angioedema because they inhibit the degradation of Bradykinin which can cause cough and angioedema.

Option 3– Overall 5 year mortality rate in heart failure is around 50% regardless of EF and type of heart failure (HFpEF or HFrEF).

Option 4– In elderly patients, AF is responsible for around 25% of strokes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1903, 1931, 1932.

questions.text: A patient comes in with headache and nausea. Upon evaluation, it was discovered that his blood pressure was 180/110 and that his K+ level was 2mEq/l. His ABG results indicated that he had metabolic alkalosis. Which syndrome might be the cause of this ailment?
questions.solution:
• The give history shows development of metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia and hypertension which are suggestive of Liddle Syndrome (option 2).
  • It is due to the overactivity of epithelial Na+ Channel in the collecting tubule (due to gain of function mutations).
  • It is Autosomal Dominant in nature .
  • Due to gain of function mutations in ENa+C(sodium channel) - There is increased/excessive absorption of Na+ and H2O into circulation causing hypertension. To maintain the electro-neutrality in the tubule lumen due to excessive sodium absorption - there is excretion of K+ and and H+ into tubule(which then come in urine) resulting in hypokalaemia & metabolic alkalosis.

Other options
  • Gitelman and Bartter syndrome both have hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but do not have high Blood pressure. Instead they have low blood pressure and present with failure to thrive. 
  • Gordon syndrome is pseudohypoaldosteronism- there is excessive activation of Na/Cl symporter in DCT leading to Excessive sodium absorption along with hypertension. This leads to less sodium being available for exchange with K+/H+ in collecting ducts leading to their retention and hence- hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis. 
 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2970

questions.text: Anti-diuretic hormone secretion was observed to be elevated in a patient after head trauma. Which of the following conclusions does not apply to this situation?
questions.solution:
Increased absorption of Na+ and H2O into circulation causing hypertension. Increased excretion of K+ and and H2O into tubule resulting in hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. SIADH is characterised by excessive unsuppressible release of ADH either from Posterior Pituitary Gland or an abnormal non-pituitary source.

Lab findings—

i. Decreased serum osmolarity ( < 275 mOsm/Kg ) ii. Increased Urine Osmolarity ( > 100 mOsm/Kg ) iii. Urinary Sodium > 40 mmol/L with normal dietary intake iv. Normal thyroid & Adrenal function

v. Normal renal function, No hydrocephalus, No Acid Base Disorders vi. Clinical euvolemia.



Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 307,351

choices.text: Scalp EEG is diagnostic of frontal lobe epilepsy
10% of healthy people have epileptiform waves on EEG
EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy
In progressive multi-focal Leucoencephalopathy lateralised epileptiform waves are seen

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about EEG is correct?
questions.solution:
5-10% of healthy people can have epileptiform waves on EEG.

Option 1 : Scalp EEG is used in the diagnosis of frontal lobe epilepsy, it is not diagnostic for frontal lobe epilepsy.

Option 3 : EEG is not mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy. 

Option 4 : In progressive multi-focal leucoencephalopathy, diffuse slow waves are seen on EEG.

 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3063
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563295/

questions.text: Which of the following medications is the only one that effectively stops the advancement of a patient's impairment in primary progressive multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder. Main target in this disease is Myelin Basic Protein (MBP).

OCRELIZUMAB : Used in primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS) management (acts by attacking mature B calls).

  • Ocrelizumab was shown in a phase 3 trial to reduce progression of clinical disability in PPMS by 24%, and also to improve other clinical and MRI markers of inflammatory and degenerative disease activity.
 
  • Ocrelizumab represents the first agent to convincingly modify the course of PPMS.
  • The dosing of ocrelizumab for PPMS is identical as for RMS.
 
  • Siponimod is a selective S1P1 S1P5 receptor modulator that was shown in a single phase 3 study to be superior to placebo in reducing the risk of progression in SPMS patients.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3473.

questions.text: Which structure is impacted in the most prevalent GBS subtypes?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option 3, b- which represents the myelin sheath of the nerve.

 GBS is a rapid onset muscle weakness caused by immune system damaging the peripheral nervous system

It is an Autoimmune disorder where the body mistakenly attacks Myelin Sheath (MOLECULAR MIMICRY).

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy ( AIDP ) is the most common type of GBS.

In AIDP, the immune response damages myelin, which is the covering that protects axons and promotes the efficient transmission of nerve impulses.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition 3501,3502,3505

choices.text: Length from Nose to Xiphoid process to umbilicus
Length from Nose to tragus of ear to umbilicus
Length from Nose to tragus of ear to xiphoid process
Length from mouth to tragus of ear xiphoid process

questions.text: Choose the best way to gauge an adult's nasogastric tube length.
questions.solution:
Nasogastric tube ( Ryle’s tube ) is used for administration of drugs, oral agents and feeding. It can also be used for Nasogastric aspiration. The length required is calculated as the distance from nose to tragus of ear to the tip of xiphoid process.

Process of insertion of Ryles Tube: -
1. Lubricate Ryles tube with lignocaine jelly
2. Ask the patient to flex his neck 45 degrees in sitting position
3. Slowly insert the tube through nose and ask patient to take sips of water
4. Check the proper insertion by auscultation and aspiration technique
5. Secure the tube by taping it




Reference-:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10439641/

questions.text: What is the most typical reason for bladder outlet obstruction in young male children?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of Bladder Outlet Obstruction (BOO) in a male child is posterior urethral valve.
  • Posterior urethral valve is the most severe form of obstructive uropathy.
  • Usually affects boys & often presents in the post - natal period.

Clinical features—

—Post micturition dribbling.

—Increased frequency of micturition. 

—Frequent UTI’s.

—Hydronephrosis due to urinary pathway obstruction and uraemia .

Key hole sign seen. (PYQ)



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2789

questions.text: Which of the following is not a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS)?
questions.solution:
Lower Urinary Tracy Symptom ( LUTS ) refer to a group of urinary problems related to storage, voiding, and post-voiding issues and occur due to Bladder, Prostate & Urethral disorders. These include

1. Voiding Symptoms

  • Hesitancy 
  • Poor Stream 
  • Intermittent Flow 
  • Incomplete emptying 
  • Post Void Dribbling 
  • Overflow incontinence
     

2. Storage Symptoms

  • Frequency 
  • Nocturnal 
  • Urgency
  • Urge Incontinence.
Incontinence during intercourse (option 1), though it can be a symptom of pelvic floor dysfunction, is not a classical lower urinary tract symptom.
 

Reference:  Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1448.

questions.text: A patient complains of hematuria and visits the OP. High grade transitional cell carcinoma is found in the urine, and a 2x2 cm bladder tumour is visible on a CT scan. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Bladder cancer is of 3 types—

  • 1. Transitional Cell Cancer (Most Common)
  • 2. Squamous Cell Cancer 
  • 3. Adenocarcinoma

It clinically presents with gross painless hematuria. NAT2 and GSTM1 are consistent germline markers for bladder cancer.

For Superficial Bladder Cancer (not invading muscle layer) : Transurethral resection of bladder tumor and Intravesical chemotherapy is done. Intravesical immunotherapy (BCG) is also done in high grade tumors.

Neo adjuvant chemo followed by TURB is done for for T3 AND T4 stage tumor with local invasion.
For advanced deep layer bladder cancer (Invasive bladder Cancer)—Radical Cystectomy is done followed by radiotherapy.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1517.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the components of Reynolds' Pentad?
(i) Fever
(ii) Hypotension
(iii) Altered Mental Status
(iv) Malena
(v) Vomiting
(vi) Pain
(vii) Jaundice
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. i,ii,iii,vi,vii

Reynold’s Pentad is a collection of signs and symptoms involved in Ascending cholangitis.

* It includes-

1. Intermittent fever 

2. Intermittent Pain 

3. Intermittent Jaundice 

4. Septic Shock

5. Altered Mental Status.

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page No 1408.

questions.text:
Which one of the following statements about HCC is true?
(i) Global incidence of HCC is rising
(ii) NASH & NAFLD are risk factors
(iii) LENVATINIB is used in tumors of size < 3.5 cm
(iv) TACE is done for multi-modular tumor
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. i, ii, iv

Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of liver. Global incidence of HCC is rising. Liver Cirrhosis, NASH and NAFLD are some of the risk factors.

* Management of HCC:

1. Localised disease—Small tumors are resected by maintaining functional liver reserve (>25%) .In case of low functional liver reserve, liver transplant is done . FLR can be increased by Nimura’s technique or ALPP’s procedure ( Associating Liver Partition and Portal vein ligation for Staged Hepatectomy ) in some cases.

2. Advanced disease—SUNITINIB, LENVATINIB, SORATENIB , TACE (Trans arterial chemo embolization ),TARE (Trans arterial radio embolization) and Radio frequency ablation.

Lenvatinib is a systemic treatment for advanced HCC, often used when surgical options like liver transplantation or resection are not feasible. It is typically used for patients with advanced-stage HCC or those who cannot undergo resection or liver transplantation.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1214.

questions.text:
Which statement concerning colon cancer is correct?
(i) Metformin reduces the risk of Colon Cancer
(ii) Right and Left Colon cancers have different clinical presentation
(iii) Colon cancers frequently metastasise to liver
(iv) Colon cancers can be hereditary
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1. i, ii, iii, iv
 
  • Colon cancer is the cancer of the Large intestine & Rectum. They may be hereditary in form of syndromes like peutz-jegher or cowden syndrome. Clinical features depend on the site of cancer and are different in left and right sided cancer.
  • MC site of distant metastasis : Liver.
  • MC death in colon cancer : Liver Mets.
  • Metformin is beneficial in reducing the risk of colon cancer.


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1360.

questions.text: What is the flow rate through the specified cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 96 ml/min

The given cannula is a green cannula which typically has flow rates of 90-105 ml/min.
Highly controversial question but mark 96ml/min if asked in INI-CET since the cannula given below is from AIIMS, Delhi itself. 

      

In a patient with massive bleeding, there is always a risk of the patient going into shock and the widest bore cannula available showed be used for cannulation.
The ATLS guidelines recommend securing intravenous access with two large-bore cannulas (14-16G) in a patient needing resuscitation. 


Mnemonic for Colour coding of Cannula-
Oh Great God Please Bless Your People
Oh- Orange- 14G
Great- Grey- 16G
God- Green- 18G
Please- Pink- 20G
Bless- Blue- 22G
Your- Yellow- 24G
People- Purple- 26G



Reference: ATLS® Advanced Trauma Life Support®, American College of Surgeons, 10th Edition, Page No 52.

questions.text: A drain as shown in the given image was placed in operative bed post right sided modified radicle mastectomy. What type of drain is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Closed

A surgical drain is a tube used to remove pus, blood or other fluids from a wound. The given image shows a Romovac drain which is a closed type of drain. There are 3 types of drains :

Closed drains : Utilise suction action for drainage. 

Semi - Open drain : Utilise the principle of capillary action. 

Open drain : Utilise the effect of gravity for drainage.

* [Extra Edge]: Current role of drain placement in gastrointestinal surgery


+ Avoid routine drain placement following

Colonic surgery

Small bowel resections
Hepatic resections
Cholecystectomy

+ Consider routine drain placement following

Oesophageal surgery

Major pancreatic resection

+ Selective use of drains following


Rectal surgery
Gastric resections


Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 115.

questions.text:
A gridiron incision was initially made on a patient who had undergone appendicectomy; this was later changed to a Rutherford Morrison incision. What structures are eliminated during this conversion?
(i) External oblique
(ii) Internal oblique
(iii) Transversus abdominis
(iv) Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1.  i, ii, iii

Gridiron incision : A muscle splitting incision involving external oblique and internal oblique. 

Rutherford Morrison Incision : It is a muscle cutting incision that cuts through external oblique, internal oblique and transverse abdominis.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, The BIOLOGICAL BASIS of MODERN SURGICAL PRACTICE, 21st Edition, Page No 1306.

questions.text:
A patient with a midline neck enlargement that shifts with deglutition arrives to the OPD. He also has exophthalmos and tachycardia. What specific investigations are necessary in this situation?
(i) Thyroid scan
(ii) FNAC
(iii) Thyroid function tests
(iv) USG neck
(v) Anti-thyroid antibodies
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) i, iii, iv, v

The given clinical history is suggestive of Grave’s disease. Antibodies Involved are TSH receptor antibodies.

Investigations—

Thyroid function tests : Increase in TSH, T3, T4. 

USG Neck : Diffuse midline neck swelling. 

Anti - Thyroid Antibodies present.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 860.

questions.text: 20-year-old patient has RTA with an injury to the left forearm. There is a brachial artery laceration of 3.5 cm seen. What is the preferred technique of repair in this case?
questions.solution:
• According to the given history, patient has a brachial artery laceration of 3.5 cm length.
  • Because of an injury of this length, end to end anastomosis is not possible. Vessel injuries that cannot be repaired by primary end to end technique will require an interposition graft.
  • The most desirable graft is an autologous great saphenous vein harvested from an uninjured leg. A reverse saphenous vein graft is a saphenous vein with blood flow reversed and valves lysed. 
  • Great saphaenous vein is preferred because elastic properties, adequate size match and  non —thrombogenic.
 

Reference:Rutherfords Vascular Surgery And Endovascular Therapy 9 Edition Page no 1446

questions.text: A 60yr old post menopausal woman presents to OPD with DEXA scan reports which showed a score of -2.5. She has a history of Colle’s fracture 6 months back. She is not a smoker and doesn’t take alcohol. Which of the following should be the first line of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
• The drug of choice for osteoporosis is bisphosphonates and among them, it is alendronate as it can be administered orally unlike others which require parenteral administration.
  • The additional treatment should be calcium and vitamin D3.
  • It helps attenuate hungry bone syndrome associated with bisphosphonate therapy.
  • Since the T score is 2.5 in DEXA scan, it is diagnostic of osteoporosis. It is imperative to start the female on treatment since she has a past history of Colle's fracture. 
  •  HRT is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment due to the increased risk of breast cancer, stroke, and cardiovascular disease.

Note- Osteoporosis is a quantitative and not qualitative bone disease. Hence, the lab parameters will remain normal. 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 309

questions.text:
Match the correct option.
a. GCT i. Wide excision
b. Osteoid osteoma ii. Radiofrequency Ablation
c. Simple bone cyst iii. Intralesional steroid
d. Osteosarcoma iv. Curettage
questions.solution:
• Osteoclastoma/ giant cell tumour is usually located at the epiphyseometaphyseal junction commonly at lower end of femur.Treatment : Extended Curettage + Bone Grafting.
  • Osteoid Osteoma— It is the most common true benign tumour. Seen in children and young adolescents. Treatment : Radiofrequency ablation, Excision.
  • Simple bone cyst is a benign bone cyst usually seen in the metaphyseal region of proximal humerus.Treatment : Aspiration followed by injection of sclerosants or steroids.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumour of bone. Usually seen in metaphysis of long bones like femur. Treatment : Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 237,244

questions.text: The term for a nerve injury that results in the severing of axons while leaving the outer nerve sheath intact is:
questions.solution:
In axonotmesis, the axon of nerve is injured but with intact nerve sheath.

Can heal spontaneously but sometimes require surgical repair depending on the injury. Neuropraxia occurs due to prolonged nerve compression. No injury to nerve structure. Healing occurs spontaneously.  In neurotmesis complete transection of nerve occurs. Almost always require surgical repair.




Preference : https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22608-neuropraxia

questions.text:
Organize the following in increasing stability order.
(i) Ilizarov circle fixator
(ii) Biplanar frame at right angle
(iii) Uniplanar with one rod
(iv) Uniplanar with two rods
questions.solution:
Order of Stability—

Ilizarov Circle Fixator > Biplanar Frame at Right Angle > Uniplanar with 2 rods > Uniplanar with 1 rod.

  • Uniplanar with one rod - This is the least stable of all the options as it is constructed in only one plane with a single rod. 
  • Uniplanar with two rods - This is more stable than the previous option as it has two rods in the same plane.
  •  Biplanar frame at right angle - This is more stable than the uniplanar options as it is constructed in two planes at right angles to each other.
  • lizarov circle fixator - This is the most stable option as it is constructed in multiple planes with multiple rings and wires, providing excellent stability and control over the bone fragments.
 

Reference-:Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar  5th Edition Page nos 76, 77                     
                     Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari 5th edition Page no 374

questions.text:
Following an RTA, a patient was brought to the casualty. After being examined, it was discovered that he had a femur shaft fracture that needed to be stabilised with tibial traction. Which of the following are essential elements for skeletal traction?
(i) Thomas splint
(ii) Bohler stirrup
(iii) Steinmann pin
(iv) K wire
(v) Bohler frame
(vi) Denham’s pin
questions.solution:
Skeletal traction is a treatment method to treat broken bones.  It is a system where combination of pulleys, pins and weights are used to promote the healing of fractured bones. They are usually done in the lower body.

Equipments required for tibial Skeletal Traction—

Steinmann Pin , Bohler Stirrup, Bohler -Brawn Splint and weights to provide traction.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 141

questions.text: A patient having a cast on for a tibial fracture arrived to the emergency room complaining of pain in the affected limb. His cast was removed, and an examination revealed pain with passive flexion of the affected limb, loss of sensation in the first web space, and the presence of dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. What is the ideal course of action for moving forward?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis most likely is evolving compartment syndrome secondary to tibial fracture. 
  • Pulse is not a reliable indicator as it is the last to disappear and therefore, doppler parameters will remain normal till the very end. Therefore, we rule out option C. 
  • Note- Most common cause of compartment syndrome is Diaphyseal fracture of tibia. 
  • Most common cause of compartment syndrome in children is supracondylar fracture of humerus.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 47

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct sequence for performing the Thomas test?
(i) Squaring of pelvis
(ii) Flexion of hip
(iii) Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis
(iv) Measure actual flexion deformity
(v) Ensure that ischial tuberosity touches the ground
(vi) Overcorrection of the normal side.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is option C- 32654
Thomas test is used for diagnosis of flexion deformity of hip. 

Steps-

1. Patient is asked to lay supine to check for exaggerated lumbar lordosis. 

2. Ask the patient to flex the hip gradually. 

3. If flexion of hip is done beyond normal limit, it will result in overcorrection of the normal side in the form of lifting up of pelvis.  This can be avoided by ensuring both the ischial tuberosities touch the ground. 

4. When the ischial tuberosities will touch the ground, the affected hip will come to lie in its deformed diseased position of flexion deformity. 

5. Measure the angle between the affected thigh and ground to obtain actual degree of flexion of deformity. 



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 432

questions.text:
Match the following with correct response:
(a) Social smile (i) 1-2 months
(b) Pincer grasp (ii) 5-6 months
(c) Walks 1-2 steps (iii) 9-11 months
(d) Transfer objects (iv) 12-13 months
questions.solution:
Milestone matched with age

1. Social smile (smile after being talked to)— 2 months.

2. Pincer grasp (mature)— 11-12 months ; Immature pincer grasp - 9 months

3. Creeps well; walks but falls; stands without support—12-13 months

4. Unidextrous reach (reaching out for objects with one hand); transfers objects— 6-7 months.










Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 182

questions.text:
Which of the following can lead to seizures in newborns?
(i) Hyponatremia
(ii) Hypernatremia
(iii) Hypocalcemia
(iv) Hypomagnesemia
questions.solution:
• Neonatal seizures are usually the clinical manifestation of a serious underlying disease.
  • They are medical emergencies because they signal a disease process that may produce irreversible brain damage.
  • A seizure is a paroxysmal behaviour caused by hyper - synchronous discharge of a group of neurons.

They can be Subtle, Tonic, Clonic, Myoclonic.
Metabolic Causes—Hypoglycemia, Hypocalcemia, Hypomagnesemia, Hyponatremia, Hypernatremia.

Memorizing Trick- All Hypo cause neonatal seizures 



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 553

questions.text: What is the most frequent cause of newborn meningitis?
questions.solution:
Paediatric meningitis causes—

0 - 2 months : E. coli followed by Staphylococcus aureus, Group B Streptococci, Listeria monocytosis,Klebsiella

2 months - 2 years : Haemophilus Influenzae, Streptococcus pneumonia 

2 years - 20 years : Meningococcus, Pneumococcus.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 561

questions.text: When does a newborn reach half the height of an adult?
questions.solution:
1. A normal child at birth is 50 cm long. Its height increases by 25 cm by 1 year of life (75 cm at the end of 1 year) and by 12-13 cm in the next year (87-88cm at the end of 2 years). Thereafter, it steadily increases by 6 cm per year.
  2. A baby reaches half of their adult height by 18-24 months (2 years) of age. (Adult height is 160-170 cm, height at 2 years is 87 cm)
  3. Height doubles by 4 years (birth length is 50cm, height is 100 cm at 4 years)
  4. It triples by 12 years of age (150cm).


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 142

questions.text:
Based on verbal autopsy data for India from 2013, list the neonatal mortality causes in descending order.
(i) Prematurity
(ii) Birth asphyxia
(iii) Sepsis
(iv) Congenital anomalies
questions.solution:
Causes of mortality in neonates according to WHO data—(in decreasing order)

  • Prematurity 
  • Intrapartum events like asphyxia 
  • Sepsis 
  • Congenital Anomalies 
  • Pneumonia.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 643.

questions.text: A newborn who is 14 days old and with fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, and rapid breathing comes to the OPD. An X-ray of his chest revealed infiltrates on both sides. Which infection is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The given history is suggestive of ophthalmia neonatorum (B/L Conjunctivitis) progressing to pneumonia. (Rapid breathing and infiltrates on chest X-Ray)

Neonatal Conjunctivitis is also known as ophthalmia neonatorum.
It can arise due to various causes (bacterial conjunctivitis, viral etc). Most common infectious cause is Chlamydia trachomatis infection. It usually occurs with 5 - 14 days of birth. Neonatal conjunctivitis + pneumonia with bilateral infiltrates strongly suggests Chlamydia trachomatis infection. 

Other options

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae - Rare in neonates, occurs in older children & adolescents. Hence, unlikely.
  • Haemophilus influenzae - Uncommon in newborns; usually causes epiglottitis, otitis media, or meningitis
  • Streptococcus - Can cause neonatal pneumonia but does not cause conjunctivitis

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 427.

questions.text: A newborn who is 14 weeks old and with fever, bilateral conjunctivitis, and rapid breathing comes to the OPD. An X-ray of his chest revealed infiltrates on both sides. Which infection is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Chlamydia

Chlamydia trachomatis is indicated in neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis that is caused within 4 weeks of birth. It later progresses to cause pnuemonia.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 427.

questions.text: Identify the given speculum
questions.solution:
Cusco’s speculum is a self retaining, bivalved speculum used for vaginal and cervical examination.





Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology, 8th edition, Page no 528, 529.

questions.text: Which emergency contraception is most popular in India?
questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel is the most commonly used emergency contraceptive.

Dose—

  • 0.75 mg X 2 tablets, 12 hours apart within 72 hours of intercourse
  • OR 1 mg single dose within 72 hours of intercourse.

Other methods of emergency contraception—

  • Ulipristal, mifepristone and IUCDs.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 575.

questions.text: Except for ________, every method of birth control is long-term and reversible.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, tubal sterilisation is an irreversible method of contraception. Other options are examples of Long Acting Reversible Contraceptives.

They include —Intrauterine devices - Hormonal, Non - Hormonal , Implants and Injectables.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 257, 268, 272, 273.

questions.text: Determine the patient's bishop score based on the following information: posterior location, soft consistency, cervix at station -1, 1 cm dilated, 30% effaced.
questions.solution:
Bishop’s scoring system is used as a pre - labour scoring system to assist in predicting whether induction of labour will required.

According to Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition: If score >= 9 : Cervix is favourable & induction is successful. 
If <= 6 : Cervix is not favourable, induction is unlikely to be succesful, ripening of cervix is needed.
According to NICE guidelines: A score of >= 6 is considered favourable

For station of -1, score is 2.

For 1-2 cm dilation, score is 1.

For 0-30% effacement, score is 0.

Posterior position, score is 0.

Soft cervical consistency also equals to a score of 2.

Total score— 5.

Bishop's score:
Score
0 1 2 3
Position Posterior Middle Anterior --
Consistency Firm Medium Soft --
Effacement 0-30% 40-50% 60-70% 80%+
Dilation Closed 1-2 cm 3-4 cm 5+cm
Station -3 -2 -1/0 +1/+2

Addition factors: +1 point for each previous vaginal birth, -1 point for first time birth givers
Add the score for each factor.
Scores lower than 5 suggest labour will not begin without induction.
Scores 9 and higher indicate labour will likely begin spontaneously.
Scores 3 and lower may indicate that an induction would not be successful.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 488.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 486.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains to the OP that her vaginal discharge is green and itchy locally. The cervix seems to be a strawberry upon close inspection. What is the course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole
This is a typical case of green vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis.
Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite)
Women with it may notice
Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals;
Discomfort when peeing; and A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell.
Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days. Partner is also given the same treatment. 
Alternative Regimen for Women and Men. Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman complains of vaginal discharge and localised itching. The results of a Pap test revealed the following image. What might be the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Gardenella vaginalis
The history of vaginal itching with presence of CLUE CELLS indicate Bacterial vaginosis causes by Gardenella vaginalis.
Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by adherent gram-negative rods, observed in vaginal smears from women with bacterial vaginosis.
AMSEL CRITERIA IS USED FOR DIAGNOSIS OF BV

Amsel Criteria for Diagnosis of BV: Three of the following four criteria must be met. Establishes accurate diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in 90% of affected women.

1) Homogeneous, non-clumping vaginal discharge (color and amount may vary)

2) Amine (fishy) odor when potassium hydroxide solution is added to vaginal secretions (commonly) called the "whiff test")

3) Presence of clue cells (greater than 20%) on microscopy

4) Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 330, 331.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is most prevalent in a person with Asherman syndrome?
questions.solution:
Asherman syndrome is an acquired uterine condition that occurs when adhesions form inside the uterus and/or the cervix. It can arise following dilation and curettage (D & C) performed after a miscarriage, delivery or abortion, pelvic surgeries like Caesarean section, myomectomy. Patients present with menstrual abnormalities (hypomenorrhea), infertility, pain during menstruation and ovulation, miscarriages.
Treatment : Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 123, 147.

questions.text: What dexamethasone dosage is recommended for foetal lung development during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Antenatal steroids are indicated in pregnant women who are at risk of delivering early (<34 weeks) as they help in maturation of foetal lung and helps prevent respiratory distress syndrome in neonates.
Steroids are given as—Dexamethasone : 6 mg X 4 doses (12 hours apart), Betamethasone : 12 mg X 2 doses (24 hours apart). 

Steroid dosage Memorizing Trick-
Dexamethasone- Dexa similar to Hexa- 6- 6 mg every 12 hours 4 injections
Betamethasone- B- 2nd letter of albhabet- 2 dosage twice the dose of Dexa and gap- 12 mg 2 injections 24 hours apart



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 802.

questions.text: According to the IADPSG, the suggested one step test for gestational diabetes using 75 g of oral glucose has a fasting glucose threshold of:
questions.solution:
For IADPSG criteria, an OGTT is done in the fasting state using 75g of glucose at 24 - 28 weeks of gestation.

GDM is diagnosed if any of the following cut - off is met : 

Fasting : >= 92 mg/dl 

1 hour : >= 180 mg/dl 

2 hours : >= 153 mg/dl.


Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1079.

questions.text: Young women undergo Pap smears primarily for:
questions.solution:
• Pap smear is a method of cervical screening used in detection of precancerous and cancerous processes in the cervix.
  • Abnormal findings if present are followed up by more sensitive diagnostic procedures.
  • It is usually taken when female is not menstruating. Pap smear is started at 21 years of age irrespective of age at first intercourse.
  • It is repeated every 3 years.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 7, 411.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding clomiphene citrate is false?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene has a side effect that it causes multi-follicular development. Thus could lead to twins. 
Monofollicular development occurs with the use of Letrozole.





Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 222, 313, 314, 316.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl complained of voice changes, irregular periods, and more facial hair. Large ovaries measuring 30 ml and 40 ml were seen on an abdominal USG. Which of the subsequent is given as the initial course of treatment?
(i) Weight reduction
(ii) OCP
(iii) Spironolactone
(iv) Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. i, ii, iii
 
  • The given history is suggestive of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome.
  • It is the most common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age group. Clinical features include irregular or absence menstrual cycle, excessive facial and body hair, acne, infertility and acanthosis nigricans.



 


Management:
—Weight Loss
—Metformin : To deal with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome
—OCPs : To regularise menstrual cycles, to treat hirsutism
—Infertility-
First Line : Letrozole (DOC), Clomiphene Citrate, Bromocriptine
Second Line : Human menopausal gonadotropin, Laparoscopic Ovarian drilling
Third Line : Synthetic GnRH.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314.

choices.text: Manual support to perineum to maintain deflexed head

questions.text: Which of the following should be done in the management of the second stage of labour, according to the most recent WHO guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hot compress to prevent perineal tear

WHO Guidelines for 2nd stage of labour :

They are practiced to reduce perineal tears during delivery of child. They include: 

1. No routine episiotomy (Option 3)

2. Modified Ritgen's maneuver :

Manual support to perineum with right hand while delivering the head of foetus, flexing head of foetus with left hand.

3. Hot compress to the perineum 

Other options: 
Option 1: It is recommended any position that is comfortable to mother, including upright position.
Option 4: Head is delivered by maintaining Flexion, NOT Deflexion




Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 429.
DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 129.

questions.text: What is the carbetocin dose used in PPH?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 100 microgram 
 

  • Carbetocin (long acting oxytocin) is typically administered as a single 100 microgram intravenous (IV) dose immediately after the delivery of the baby to help prevent PPH.
  • Carbetocin 100 µg intravenously is recommended for elective cesarean section for the prevention of PPH and for the reduction of additional uterotonics in the 2018 Society of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists of Canada guideline



Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 477.
Online source https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546425/

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with primary amenorrhea visits the OP. Breast development, pubic hair growth, and axillary hair growth were all normal upon evaluation. Uterus was not visible on a USG. What could the diagnosis be?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the patient has normal secondary sexual characters (Breast developed, pubic and axillary hair present) but uterus is absent. This is more suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. It arises due to absence of both mullerian ducts, hence fallopian tube, uterus, cervix and upper vagina are absent.

Patient has normal karyotype and normal secondary sexual characters. Management : Vaginoplasty

Female can’t menstruate or become pregnant but can take part in IVF treatment + Surrogacy.

 
MRKH AIS
Genotype XX Genotype XY
Normal female serum T levels Normal male T levels
Normal female pubic and axillary Decreased pubic and axillary hair
Normal female height Increased height compared with female counterparts
Normal ovaries located high on the pelvic side wall Intra-abdominal testicles
No increased risk of gonadal malignancy Gonads removal recommended after puberty due to increased risk of malignancy



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 143, 145.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used to distinguish between obstructed vas deferens and testicular failure in male azoospermia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. FSH levels

  • The best test to differentiate between obstructive and non - obstructive azoospermia is serum FSH levels.
  • Absence of sperms in semen is azoospermia. Azoospermia is classified as non obstructive azoospermia (NOA) or obstructive azoospermia (OA). NOA occurs when there is an impairment of spermatogenesis, whilst OA is caused by occlusion of the testicular and genital ductular system.
  • FSH levels may be decreased in pretesticular azoospermia and elevated in testicular azoospermia (Non obstructive causes). While FSH levels are normal in post testicular azoospermia which is obstructive.







Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 207-210.

questions.text: What prevents milk production during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• High estrogen
  • High estrogen during pregnancy will keep the prolactin levels suppressed which prevents lactation.
  • The local effects of estrogen and progesterone in the breast prevent milk secretion during pregnancy. With their withdrawal in the postpartum period, the stimulating effect of the anterior pituitary hormone prolactin dominates and milk secretion is initiated and maintained.


Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 54, 141.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with diabetes and hypertension presented herself at the OPD complaining of vaginal bleeding for the previous month. What would be the best investigation for her?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Endometrial biopsy

Diabetes, hypertension and vaginal bleeding are seen in high Estrogen State of corpus cancer syndrome.

Hence, Endometrial biopsy should be done to rule out cancer


    



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 433-435.
